commitResults.messageTitle: [#452] HotFix: GitLogTest fails due to system time >= 2019  (#455)
commitResults.messageBody:
GitLogTest#gitLog_sinceDateInFuture_noContent() test method has a check
which asserts that if the until date given is before any of the
repository's commit date, the git log command should not give any
commmit info.

However, after the new year in year 2019, the test now fails. This may
be due to the Year 2038[1] problem. As the given until date is too
early (year 1950), this causes the time difference to overflow. As
such, a future until date is formed instead, causing git log to give
all the commit info, thus the test fails.

As a hotfix for this issue, let's set an earlier until date
(year 2010) for the test instead.

As this check is also not within the scope of the test method,
gitLog_sinceDateInFuture_noContent(), let's refactor it out to
a different test method, gitLog_untilDateBeforeAnyCommit_noContent.

[1]: Description of the Year 2038 problem:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Year_2038_problem

commitResults.messageTitle: [#411] DeveloperGuide: update outdated gradle command in setup (#416)
commitResults.messageBody:
In `Verifying the setup part` of Developer Guide, the gradle command 
to run the tests given is `gradlew test functional`.

However, the functional task in gradlew has been renamed to systemtest
in #306 and therefore the command should be updated to
`gradlew test systemtest` correspondingly.

Let's correct this outdated command in the Developer Guide instructions.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#394] Report#Toolbar: remove lowercase conversion in search bar (#420)
commitResults.messageBody:
The search bar allows lowercase inputs only (i.e., it auto-changes the
user-input to lowercase).

This is unnecessary as it can confuse the user about the keywords
entered.

Let's 
* display the text on the search bar as it is entered by the user. 
* convert the keyword internally, hidiing it from the user.
* Update the UserGuide to indicate that the search is case-insensitive.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#652] ChartView: fix url directing to wrong repository (#655)
commitResults.messageBody:
The Octocat icon links to a GitHub repository by using the index 0 to
get the URL of the first repository.

When summary charts are grouped by Author, different repositories 
under the same Author to all link to the same URL as the first 
repository.

Let's update the URL to point to their respective repository by
referencing with the correct index.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#672] Toolbar: set 'commit' as default for granularity (#684)
commitResults.messageBody:
The default value of granularity is `Day`.

`Commit` as granularity is more closer to reality because users are more
likely to observe per commits rather than per day/week. Users can choose
a more summarized view at their discretion.

Let's change the default value for granularity to `Commit`.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#699] Report: standardize the author's name display (#701)
commitResults.messageBody:
When summary charts are grouped by none or repo/branch, author's name
display shows only the display name. Whereas when grouped by author,
the name display shows the display name as well as GitHub username.

This causes inconsistency in the name display. Furthermore, user won't
be able to refer to the author's GitHub username when the summary
charts are not grouped by author.

Let's standardize all the name display using the format,
[display name] (github username).

commitResults.messageTitle: [#635] CodeView: add line number to code (#669)
commitResults.messageBody:
The code view displays only the code without the line number.

It is hard to associate a specific line from the code view with the
actual code without the line number.

Let's update the code view to display the line numbers by adding an
array in each segment to keep track of the line numbers of the code.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#702] Fix url directing to the wrong branch (#704)
commitResults.messageBody:
The Octocat icon always links to the master branch of a GitHub 
repository.

Octocat icons of summary charts that are not within the master 
branch will still point to the URL of the master branch.

Let's update the URL to point to their respective branch.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#664] Toolbar: expand width for `breakdown by file format` (#685)
commitResults.messageBody:
The width of label `breakdown by fileformat` is set to 110px which
displays in two lines even though there are enough room for it to
display in a single line.

This will cause the label to not look as organised as compared to the
label being displayed in a single line.

Let's expand the width for `breakdown by file format` by setting the
width as fit-content to ensure that the label is displayed in a single
line.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#663] ChartView: add total contribution of group (#697)
commitResults.messageBody:
A group only shows the total contribution of each author or repo/branch
within the group but not the total contribution of all combined.

It is rather difficult for the user to compare the total contribution
between groups as the user would need to sum up the contribution of each
row in order to get the total contribution of a group.

Let's display the total contribution of groups beside the group title so
that it is easier for the user to do comparisons between groups.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#647] Toolbar: rename values in `sort group by` (#668)
commitResults.messageBody:
The `sort groups by` selection contains the option of `repo/branch` and
`name` when charts are grouped by Repo/Branch and Author respectively.

As it is a `sort group by` selection, there's is no need to use two
different options `repo/branch` and `name` as they both refer to the
`group name`

Let's rename both values to `group name` to standardize the values.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#660] ChartView: remove ramp slices not within date range (#670)
commitResults.messageBody:
After adjusting the date range, ramp slices that are not within the 
date range still shows in the ramp row.

Users would only want to see the ramp slices that are within the date 
range.

Let's remove the ramp slices that are not within date range by 
checking if the position of the ramp slices are within the width of 
the ramp row (if it is not within the width of the ramp row, the ramp
slice is not within date range) before adding the ramp slices to the 
ramp row.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#712] ChartView: fix misalignment of chart title (#715)
commitResults.messageBody:
When 'breakdown by file format' is checked, the title of a chart aligns
beside the contribution bars of the previous chart when the
contribution bars' height of exceeds the margin allocated.

Let's fix this misalignment by adding css property 'clear:left' to the
chart title so that the chart title will always start at a new line.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#689] v_summary.js: remove unused remnants code (#733)
commitResults.messageBody:
Unused code was found in v_summary.js; specifically code associated
with the variable, filterSortReverse. They are remnants left behind by
the improvement of sort controls introduced in #618.

The unused code was originally bind to the reverse checkbox in the
older version of RepoSense. As the checkbox was replaced by the
introduction of ascending and descending options in #618, the code is
now unused and redundant. This is also partially due to the complexity
brought upon by new sorting group, the reversing has to be done within
the code of descending's logic, rendering those code not reusable.

Let's remove the unused code associated to the variable, 
filterSortReverse and it's implementations.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#645] CodeView: improve UI of sort bar (#716)
commitResults.messageBody:
In the UI of sortbar: 
- The font size of 3 controls (searchbar, checkbox, sort) are different
- The sorting option's position is below the radio controls
- The font of reverse checkbox is red in colour
- The gaps between sorting option and radio controls is not 
standardized

Lets:
- Standardize the font size of all 3 controls so that the sort bar
looks neater
- Shift sorting option to be above radio controls to further
emphasize the number of radio buttons better
- Set the font of reverse checkbox to be black in color to
differentiate from other checkboxes and to be consistent with the
ChartView
- Standardize the gaps between sorting option and radio controls

commitResults.messageTitle: [#720] Set command-click to activate zoom-in feature for macOS devices (#730)
commitResults.messageBody:
Ctrl + mouse left-click is the default combination to activate the
zoom-in feature for all environment.

However, as the combination is registered as a right-click in macOS
environment, users of macOS devices wouldn't be able to activate the
corresponding feature.

Let's modify the zoom-in controls to allow command click for macOS 
devices and control click for all other devices.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#666] CodeView: load un-authored code only when toggled (#740)
commitResults.messageBody:
Viewing the changes in code of an author causes the app to 
render all authored and un-authored segments within modified files.
A small change in large file will cause the entire file to be preloaded.

When an author has small changes done to a lot of large files, it will
lead to an unresponsive page as loading the large un-authored segments
will affect the rendering speed. Furthermore, the preloading of all 
un-authored code is not necessary as users might only view the 
un-authored code under certain circumstances. (e.g. when the user 
does not understand why the author added the authored code)

Let's modify the app to only load the un-authored code when the 
user toggles the 'Show untouched code' icon.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#741] Fix view code icon not opening CodeView (#744)
commitResults.messageBody:
The splitCommitsWeek() method executes a dateRounding() method that 
rounds up the filterSinceDate to the next nearest Monday. When the 
report page is reloaded, the filterSinceDate is set to the value of 
the 'since' hash by the getDates() method. Since within the 
getFiltered() method, splitCommitsWeek() is executed before
getDates(), the filterSinceDate stores an empty string which is 
passed to the dateRounding() method and returns a NaN value. 

Since splitCommitsWeek() method is only called when granularity is 
'week', if users were to set granularity as 'week' and reload the page,
clicking on the view code icon does not open the CodeView panel. 

Let's shift the getDates() method to be executed before 
splitCommitsWeek() to make sure that splitCommitWeek() method
is called with a valid filterSinceDate, which fixes the described bug.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#680] Vue: fix error message in development mode (#742)
commitResults.messageBody:
An error message stating "error compiling template: - <template>
cannot be keyed. Place the key on real elements instead." was found in
Chrome browser's console when running Vue in development mode for our
report.

Although the Vue development tool still functions correctly, it 
highlights an issue with the existing style and possibility degrades 
the efficiency of the operations.

Let's remove the Chrome browser console error by shifting the binding 
of keys from the <template> tag to the inner <label> tag.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#770] Add placeholder for repositories with no author found (#777)
commitResults.messageBody:
Repositories with no author specified in the configuration files as
well as no commits made during the specified period do not appear in
the report.

This is caused by a TypeError in JavaScript. When an author
configuration can't be found for a repository, RepoSense will perform
the identification of the authors using the commits. However, in the
event that even commits cannot be found, author information will not be
available and result in the error stated above.

As users may not notice the disappearance of these repositories, let's
add a placeholder with an error message of 'NO AUTHOR WITH COMMITS
FOUND WITHIN THIS PERIOD OF TIME' to the affected repositories to
inform users of the occurrence of this error.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#312] CodeView: reduce space taken by toggle icon (#773)
commitResults.messageBody:
The toggle icon that separates between untouched and touched code 
segments within the CodeView takes up significant amount of extra space.

The extra white space causes the code to be in a different layout than 
its actual layout.

Let's place the toggle icon on the side of the code to not disrupt the 
layout of the code while saving the extra space taken by the current
toggle icon.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#748] Restore authorship tab (#749)
commitResults.messageBody:
Reloading the report page with the authorship tab opened will result
to a closed authorship tab.

The info.name property is only created when clicking on the view code
icon and calling openTabAuthorship() method of v_summary. The
initiate() method of v_authorship sets the isTabActive property to be 
false if info.name property does not exist. Reloading the report page 
does not call openTabAuthorship(), which means that the info.name 
property will not exist and the isTabActive is false regardless of 
url value.

Let's modify the initiate() method of v_authorship.js to check for
info.author property instead of info.name as the property exists 
when reloading the page as well as clicking on the view code icon.
This modification properly restores the last viewed authorship tab, 
if any.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#791] CodeView: bugfix for unexpected colors in line numbers (#792)
commitResults.messageBody:
The css property of line number only overwrites the color property of 
classes 'hljs-number' and 'hljs-comment'. Others classes such as
'hljs-quote', 'hljs-name' and more are not overwritten.

This will cause the color property of certain line numbers to inherit 
from the hljs classes that are not overwritten.

Let's overwrite all hljs classes to ensure the color property of the 
line number to always be grey.

commitResults.messageTitle: ChartView: highlight error messages in red (#790)
commitResults.messageBody:
Within ChartView, ramp charts with error messages are blended together 
with the other ramp charts without error messages as they both have 
similar UI.

Let's modify the UI of ramp charts with error messages to use red color 
for their info message font to distinguish itself from other ramp 
charts without error messages.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#811] CodeView: fix position of toggle icons (#813)
commitResults.messageBody:
The 'closer' class designated for icons that toggle code segments
is absolutely positioned. Due its parent class, 'untouched', being 
in default static position, 'closer' is positioned relatively to the 
edges of the root containing block.

When scrolling through horizontally within each code segment, the 
toggle icons remains unchanged in their position in x-axis, hovering 
over the text in code view.

Let's relatively position the 'untouched' class, which turns the class 
into a containing block. This ensures absolutely positioned elements 
contained within will be positioned relative to the edges of 'untouched'
rather than the root containing block.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#522] Implement style checker on .scss files (#803)
commitResults.messageBody:
RepoSense currently has CheckStyle and ESLint to check our java and 
javascript code styles automatically. However, .scss files are not 
covered by any of these tools.

Let's implement stylelint to check the code styles of .scss files.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#764] Toolbar: fix search functionality for Safari users (#797)
commitResults.messageBody:
The 'enter' key submits html forms in browsers such as Chrome and 
Firefox, but not in Safari.

Since the getFiltered() method is executed on submit of the html form,
Safari browser users are unable to activate the search functionality 
when search value is keyed in and 'enter' key is pressed.

Let's move the execution of getFiltered() method to be within 
updateFilterSearch(), to ensure that Safari users are also able to 
activate the search functionality.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#763] v_summary.js: remove redundant calls to getFiltered() (#800)
commitResults.messageBody:
When reloading the report page, the data in v_summary such as
filterSinceDate, filterUntilDate, filterTimeFrame etc will change based 
on the URL hash values. The changes in data will trigger the watchers 
for those data, and each of them will call getFiltered() method.

Only one call for getFiltered() is required after rendering the filter 
hash, the other getFiltered() calls by the watchers are redundant.
When the report is large in size, repeatedly executing getFiltered()
when reloading the report will also significantly affect the loading 
performance of our report.

Let's only allow watchers to execute getFiltered() after the first 
cycle of watcher updates to prevent redundant calls to getFiltered().

commitResults.messageTitle: [#724] Modify zoom-in feature to based on selected granularity (#729)
commitResults.messageBody:
The zoom-in feature opens the zoom panel to show the selected
sub-range of a ramp chart in terms of 'commit'. This feature, however, 
only works when the granularity is set to commit or day.

Users will not be able to use this feature with granularity set to week,
as the method getUserCommits() gets all user commits by interating 
through an undefined key object 'dayCommits', which stops the method
execution.

Moreover, long sub-range of ramp charts will contain dense information 
with ramp slices overlapping each other. This happens even when 
granularity is set to day or week, which makes it difficult for users to 
notice substantial info on these ramp charts.

Let's correctly implement the zoom-in feature when granularity is set to
week. Furthermore, let's modify the feature for the ramp chart within 
zoom panel to be in terms of the granularity selected, which allow users 
to observe selected granularity of commits more clearly within the 
zoomed-in range.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#780] v_summary.js: remove Vue watcher for repos (#783)
commitResults.messageBody:
A redundant Vue watcher was found in v_summary.js, specifically the Vue
watcher for repos, as repos should remain constant and not be modified.

This is primarily used to call the getUsers() method, however this 
itself is redundant as getUsers() shouldn't be called more than once 
as it tends to overwrite repos with the same set of values.

Additionally, using Vue watcher for large data, such as repos, affects 
the performance of the report.

Let's remove the Vue watcher for repos and modify getUsers() to be 
called only once when page is firstly loaded.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#820] Cypress: add sinceDate in command arguments (#821)
commitResults.messageBody:
The arguments used to generate the sample report used in Cypress 
tests is '--repo https://github.com/reposense/RepoSense.git --view'. 

Since sinceDate and untilDate is not provided in the arguments, the 
report duration will be from one month before today's date until
today's date. This causes the current sample report used for Cypress
tests to contain empty ramp charts, which does not mimic a realistic
report.

Let's add a '--since d1' argument to the existing arguments, which 
generates a more realistic sample report that contains the commits
made from start until today's date.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#70] Remove unused class Console (#108)
commitResults.messageBody:
Following the removal of GUI in #77, the Console class is left unused.
Furthermore, as it requires an additional JavaFX library which is not
used in anywhere else in the project, it creates a redundant
dependency request for the compiler.

Let's remove the unused class Console.

commitResults.messageTitle: Apply single responsibility principle to frontend component (#99)
commitResults.messageBody:
Client class performs the parsing of inputs, and functionalities that
should have been part of the main program.

This violates the single responsibility principle as every module or
class should only be responsible for a single part of the
functionality. By delegating the parsing of strings to another module,
this allows easier addition and modification of new parsers and
functionalities.

Let's add a new package parser to improve the cohesiveness and
maintainability of the codebase.

commitResults.messageTitle: Increase parsing capabilities using third-party library (#128)
commitResults.messageBody:
The program expects arguments to be given in a pair, in the form
"-argument value".

This design is not flexible as it does not allow inputs with no value
or multiple values. For example, -incremental and -config file1 file2
file3.

Let's use third-party argument parser library, ArgParse4J to increase
flexibility and functionality. It provides many quality-of-life
features, such as, flexible arguments as well as datatype conversion.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#128] Fix failing ArgParser unit tests on Windows systems (#141)
commitResults.messageBody:
ArgsParser unit tests use ClassLoader#getResource(String) to get the path to
a resource file/directory.

According to this SO post[1], ClassLoader#getResource(String) adds an extra
leading slash before a path on Windows systems, which may cause the path
we get to be invalid, resulting in all ArgsParser's unit tests to fail.

Let's update ArgsParserTest to use File(String).toPath() to prevent
the extra leading slash in Windows system.

[1]: Leading slash before disk name in Windows:
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/15662820/getresource-puts-a-leading-before-the-disk-name-using-java-1-7-windows-7

commitResults.messageTitle: [#143] Enable macOS execution environment on Travis-CI (#144)
commitResults.messageBody:
As an Java application, RepoSense is able to execute on all OSes that
supports jar executable. It is important to ensure that our application
does not break on the supported OSes.

In addition to the linux execution environment, Travis also supports CI
on macOS. Furthermore, this multi-environment configuration allows
parallel execution according to Travis-CI documentation [1].

Let's enable a second build environment, macOS, on travis, so we can
ensure RepoSense runs correctly on all supported OSes.

[1] Testing Your Project on Multiple Operating Systems:
https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/multi-os/

commitResults.messageTitle: [#60] Simplify CSV configuration file format (#130)
commitResults.messageBody:
The format of the CSV configuration file requires all white listed
authors pertaining to a repository to be written in a line.

This design may degrade user-friendliness, as it may be
more difficult to add information horizontally for repository with
large number of contributors.

Let's change the format of the CSV configuration file to one author
per line, so that the experience of adding new user is consistent.
Thus, improving user experience.

commitResults.messageTitle: Modification to accommodate netlify (#150)
commitResults.messageBody:
To validate a PR, a reviewer would have to generate the dashboard
on his/her computer which results in additional lead-time.

Let's deploy the generated dashboard to netlify to streamline the
process of validation.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#194] Fix invalid path when accessing jar resources (#196)
commitResults.messageBody:
RepoSense v1.1-rc2 executed as a JAR throws an InvalidPathException
when accessing templateZip.zip.

This is because the location of the templateZip.zip cannot be located
by its path on the disk but by its relative path in the JAR file. 

So let's change the way to retrieve templateZip.zip from 
RepoSense.class.getClassLoader().getResource("templateZip.zip") to 
RepoSense.class.getResourceAsStream("/templateZip.zip").

commitResults.messageTitle: [#56] Add support for user-supplied file formats (#159)
commitResults.messageBody:
File formats .java and .adoc are hardcoded in the git log command of
RepoSense.

As the file formats are not changable, this means RepoSense may only
be useful for users who work on repository that consisting mainly of
java or adoc.

Let's allow an optional file formats to be passed in as a parameter so
that user could use RepoSense on repositories with different codebases.

commitResults.messageTitle: Allow location to be supplied into CSV Config File (#210)
commitResults.messageBody:
Representing a repository with organization and repository name in 
the config csv file may only satisfies basic usage.

By generalizing it to location allows cloning from disk locations or
using of more complex .git links.
i.e. https://username@github.com/organization/repository.git. 

Let's use location in the config csv file to make git clone more
versatile.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#217] Support repository standalone configuration (#232)
commitResults.messageBody:
RepoSense only accepts authors information from the config csv.

This centralized way of managing authors is not scalable.

Let's use a decentralized way to retrieve authors information from
the cloned repositories to make it easy to manage authors.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#245] Change -config to use a configuration folder (#249)
commitResults.messageBody:
RepoSense uses a CSV config file for all repository information.

Following #234, analysis can be done at author level.
To make author level analysis available to the users, the CSV config
file has to be broken down into repo-config.csv and author-config.csv.

Let's start by changing cli argument -config to accept a folder to
support multiple CSV config files.

commitResults.messageTitle: Support git and disk location as CLI inputs (#241)
commitResults.messageBody:
Following #232, authors information can be decentralized to a
config.json file in a repository.

So, having another config.csv to hold repository locations just to run
RepoSense can be repetitious.

Let's allow repository locations to be supplied directly as CLI inputs
to streamline analysis of repositories with decentralized authors
information.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#244] Add repo file exclusion patterns to standalone config (#248)
commitResults.messageBody:
Following #218, file exclusion glob patterns can be supplied in the
csv config file.

Let's decentralized this setting to the _reposense/config.json so
repository owners can apply it to their repositories.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#245] Split repo and author level configurations (#238)
commitResults.messageBody:
RepoSense uses a CSV config file for all repository information.

Following #234, analysis can be done at author level.
To make author level analysis available to the users, the CSV config
file has to be broken down into repo-config.csv and author-config.csv.

Let's split the CSV config file to repo-config.csv and author-config.csv.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#275] Fix UnsupportedOperationException occurred during ignore glob list merge (#276)
commitResults.messageBody:
Arrays.asList creates a wrapper over the original array to make it
available as a list.

This makes certain operations not allowed on the wrapper, such as
adding or removing elements from the list, and result in
UnsupportedOperationException being thrown when we execute these
operations forcefully.

Let's replace it with new ArrayList<>(Arrays.asList(...)) which creates
a new List fully independent of the original array.

commitResults.messageTitle: Fix creation of many author configs (#278)
Add tests to RepoConfiguration#merge (#279)
commitResults.messageBody:
AuthorConfigCsvParser#getRepoConfiguration should return existing
RepoConfiguration from a list of RepoConfigurations. Otherwise it adds
a newly created RepoConfiguration into the list and returns it.

However, due to a bug, any RepoConfigurations existing or not are added
to the list of RepoConfigurations causing duplicates.

Let's add test to RepoConfiguration#merge to prevent bugs.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add functionality to ignore standalone config #272 (#288)
commitResults.messageBody:
RepoSense offers decentralization of configuration by allowing
repository owners to set up their own standalone config.

While this enhance the ease of use, it does not offer our users the
flexibility to overrule the standalone configuration with their own.

Let's add an additional configuration column in repo-config.csv to
forcibly use the user supplied configuration by ignoring the one
defined by the repository owner.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#271] Support specifying of file formats at repo level (#295)
commitResults.messageBody:
RepoSense allows specifying of file formats for analysis through CLI.

However, this sets all repositories to the same file formats.

Let's make file formats configurable in CSV and standalone configs
to improve usage on repositories with different file formats
and codebases.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#317] Add repo as alias to repos in CLI  (#322)
commitResults.messageBody:
RepoSense accepts repository locations with argument -repos.

The plurality is not intuitive for first-time users, who wish
to use one repository.

Let's add repo as an alias to repos to make the CLI more inituive.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#366] Fix NullPointerException when accessing unfilled displayName in StandaloneConfig (#368)
commitResults.messageBody:
In our user guide, we allow most of the fields under the authors'
configuration to be optional other than the GitHub Id. Particularly
`Display Name`, which is suppose to use GitHub Id value when it is not
provided. However, when the display name is not filled in the
standalone config, the program crashes due to a NullPointerException.

This is because standalone config adopts the json format. When a field
is not filled in, in the json file, it will be initialized as null when
deserialized into a java object. This was unforeseen and was left
unchecked when accessing the variable.

Let's fix this by returning an empty string as the default value of
display name in the event of a null case, and also include unit tests
for StandaloneConfig parser.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#413] Update Travis-CI configuration to fix pcre2 dependency (#414)
commitResults.messageBody:
Git in Travis macosx image lacked pcre2 dependency to run checkstyle.
Thus, a line was added to reinstall Git with pcre2.

However, Git is then updated to use pcre2 by default and --with-pcre2
option was removed. This missing option causes Travis to fail.

Let's remove the line to reinstall Git with pcre2 in Travis configuration
to fix the issue.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#402] Make StandaloneConfig foolproof to exceptions caused by trailing commas (#412)
commitResults.messageBody:
Extra trailing commas is non-compliant to JSON standards.

This causes gson to improperly parse a list, creating additional
null elements, resulting NullPointerException in RepoConfiguration#update.

Let's prevent NullPointerException by removing null elements in lists.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#23, #470] Use Travis-CI to automate publishing of report to GitHub Pages (#497)
commitResults.messageBody:
Travis-CI offers cron jobs, which is used to trigger builds at certain
intervals.

Together with GitHub Pages, they can be utilized to make RepoSense a
cloud application, where it can periodically run analysis and update the
report to a live site.

Let's utilize Travis-CI to automate publishing of RepoSense report to
GitHub Pages, removing manual intervention for report updating.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#527] Improve highlightjs usage to prevent report from lagging/crashing (#533)
commitResults.messageBody:
hightlightjs (`hljs`) is used for highlighting of codes in code view
giving it context and readability. It can be triggered to render an
element with `window.hljs.highlightBlock(element)`.

`hljs` operations are expensive and stateless, where it re-renders even
on a rendered DOM and uses automatic detection of programming languages
if the language is not specified. Also, multiple `hljs` operations can
be triggered at once, causing the report to lag and crash.
Additionally, it seems to render regardless of trigger for any code in
`<pre><code>`. Furthermore, in our frontend, `vuejs` will trigger `hljs`
in `Vue#update`, when there is a data change, causing DOM to be 
re-rendered.

Let's optimize hljs usage, by triggering it when code is inserted into
the DOM, enclosing the code with a different tag, specifiying the
language to prevent expensive auto detection.

commitResults.messageTitle: Remove redundant commands in Travis config (#551)
commitResults.messageBody:
In the Travis config file, we specify our Linux environment to use
JDK9 with `jdk: oraclejdk9` and `addons.apt.packages key`, but the
latter is redundant. Similarly, the command used to install frontend
npm dependencies can be simpified. The cd command does not change the
install location of the npm dependencies as frontend folder does not
contain a package.json file.

Let's remove the redundant commands for clarity and maintainability.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#537] build.gradle: fix files compilation order (#552)
commitResults.messageBody:
Nits to message:

```
We use `./gradlew run` in development to conveniently run RepoSense
without the need to build a Jar.

It is expected to do the following tasks sequentially:

[a] npmRunSpuild - build frontend/src to frontend/build
[b] zipReport    - zip `frontend/build` to resource of zip
[c] build   	 - build src to build files
[d] run          - execute the build files

However, when we execute the command, `./gradlew run --dry-run`
to list the running order, it differs from the expectation.

Actual order:
:compileJava		[c]
:processResources 	[c]
:classes 	        [c]
:downloadNode 		[a]
:npmInstall 		[a]
:npmRunSpuild 		[a]
:zipReport 	        [b]
:run 			[d]

Expected order:
:downloadNode		[a]
:npmInstall		[a]
:npmRunSpuild		[a]
:zipReport		[b]
:compileJava		[c]
:processResources	[c]
:classes		[c]
:run 			[d]

The incorrect order may result in RepoSense failing due to missing
templateZip or using an outdated templateZip.

Let's fix the issue by correctly chaining the task dependencies.
```

commitResults.messageTitle: [#537] build.gradle: change tasks dependencies to compileJava (#563)
[#557] Travis: check scripts do not work in Travis macOS environment (#559)
commitResults.messageBody:
Following #414, the line to reinstall `git` with `pcre2` was removed in
Travis macOS environment. As running `brew reinstall --with-pcre2 git`
would caused Travis to fail. Furthermore, `pcre2` now ships with
`git >= 2.19`.

Since its removal, check scripts, that depends on `pcre2`, do not work
but Travis macOS still passes. This is due to the use of an older
version of git which does not comes with `pcre2`.

Let's use the latest version of Travis macOS image, that comes with git
2.19.1, to ensure check scripts run correctly.

commitResults.messageTitle: Downgrade to JDK8 in CIs (#556)
commitResults.messageBody:
RepoSense is advertised to run on JDK 1.8.0_60 and later.

However, we use JDK 9 in our CIs.

Let's downgrade to use JDK 8 in CIs to validate this non-functional
requirement.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#480] Use Cypress to automate front-end testing (#555)
commitResults.messageBody:
UI has been relying on reviewers to test it manually. While it promotes
shorter development time, our product's reliability has suffered in the
recent UI development. 

Let's integrate Cypress into our CI to automate the front-end testing
in CI to ensure better reliability.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#584] Cypress: front-end test failing due to timeouts (#595)
commitResults.messageBody:
By default, Cypress use 4000ms as the timeout value for DOM-based
commands.

However, using the default timeout value may result in frontend test
failing, when the CI is experiencing heavier load.

Let's increase the timeout value to 30000ms.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#391] GitLsTree: validate filepaths before cloning (#564)
commitResults.messageBody:
Unix and Windows use a different set of invalid characters, with the
latter being more restrictive.

A valid file path in Unix may be invalid in Windows, which causes git
clone to fail. We classify this error generally as GitCloneException,
which may not be useful in conveying the exact cause of error.

Let's validate file paths and use a more specialized exception to log
invalid file paths, when analysis is done on Windows.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#648]: .travis.yml: change oraclejdk8 to openjdk8 (#650)
commitResults.messageBody:
The oracle-java8-installer in our .travis.yml refers to
ppa:webupd8team/java repository. According to the repo maintainer[1],
the repository has been discontinued due to "licensing issues".
Similarly, the homebrew java8[2] has been removed as well.

Let's update .travis.yml to use openjdk8 instead.

[1]: https://launchpad.net/~webupd8team/+archive/ubuntu/java
[2]: https://www.chuchur.com/article/mac-install-and-uninstall-java-jdk

commitResults.messageTitle: [#606] Enable use of deploy key for publishing (#732)
commitResults.messageBody:
In the publishing guide, instructions were given to generate personal
access token to grant write-access to RepoSense for publishing.

Despite ease of setup, personal access token may not be as secure as it
can access all other repositories owned by the user.

Let's also support deploy key for enhanced security, which enables user
to grant access to only a single repository.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#315] Make -view a flag to launch the report automatically after processing (#446)
commitResults.messageBody:
In order for users to view the report using our app, they have
to use a separate -view command after generating it with a 
-config or -repo command. 

This is a hassle to the user as it can be joined together with the main
command to form an atomic action.

Let's update -view to be a flag for users to view the report
automatically after it has been generated using the main command,
while maintaining its original functionality.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#457] Split author level configurations from RepoConfiguration (#499)
commitResults.messageBody:
Repo and author level configuration files are both represented by
RepoConfiguration class.

This makes it harder to maintain as any changes to one of the
configuration file will affect the other.

Let's create a new class AuthorConfiguration to represent the
author config file settings, splitting it from the RepoConfiguration.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#476] CLI: -view should not accept a PATH when used with -config or -repos (#541)
commitResults.messageBody:
When -view option is given with an argument and is used together
with -config or -repos option, no analysis will be performed, but a
server will be launched at the path specified by the -view option.

This may be unintuitive and insecure for users as they might expect an
analysis to be performed since a -config or -repos option was given.

Lets fix this issue by performing the analysis when -view option is
given with an argument and used together with -config or -repos, and
launching a server to view the report generated by the analysis
afterwards.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#540] Perform cloning in parallel with analyzing (#560)
commitResults.messageBody:
Repos are processed sequentially, one at a time.

As cloning does not takes much processing power and analysis does not
take any network bandwidth, the two can be done in parallel to reduce
the total processing time.

Here are some test results to support the above hypothesis:
The test was performed using CS2103 AY1819S1 project repos on my local
machine. The average time taken to generate the report was measured
across 10 runs. Current code took 17 min 21s while new implementation
took 11 min 55s.

Let's clone the next repo in the list while the current repo is being
analyzed.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#390] repo-config.csv: provide override prefix (#602)
commitResults.messageBody:
In our implementation, Standalone config has the utmost priority; such
that the user is unable to override any of the fields without disabling
it.

However, there may be cases where user may want to import only certain
fields (e.g. authors) and discard/reconfigure the others. One example
of this can be to import the details of the authors, but change the
file formats of the analysis.

Let's provide the override functionality in the repo-config.csv file
using the prefix "override:".

commitResults.messageTitle: [#609] Console output: make logs clearer after cloning in parallel (#616)
commitResults.messageBody:
After #560, log messages during analysis of a repository became unclear
as there can be another repository being cloned at the same time.

This causes the log messages of the two repositories to interleave with
one other, which can be confusing, and reduces the usefulness of the
log messages.

Lets add repository information (including location and branch) to the
log messages to make it clearer which repository is being cloned or
analyzed.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#337] RepoCloner: use single clone to analyze multiple branches of a repository (#625)
commitResults.messageBody:
When analyzing multiple branches of a repository, RepoSense will clone
that same repository as many times as the number of the branches if
they are not listed consecutively in the config file.

This is inefficient as all the analysis were performed against the same
repo. Hence, there shouldn't be a necessity to clone it multiple times.

Lets use a single clone to analyze multiple branches of a repository
regardless of the order they are listed in the config file.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#613] author-config#email: include + operator infinite email matcher (#617)
commitResults.messageBody:
In some cases, instead of allocating the simple default email to the
user using just the GitHub ID, GitHub allocates them prefixed with
numbers and the + operator. For e.g.
35282962+githubid@users.noreply.github.com. The + operator is commonly
used in mail servers, such as Google, as aliases or means to allow
users to possess infinite number of emails while having them remain
identifiable.

By adding this pattern into our email matcher, this will increase
more number of authors that can be identified by default, hence
increase the convenience of our users.

Lets add this pattern into our email matcher.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#637] ContributionBar: length changes on breakdown option selected (#638)
commitResults.messageBody:
Contribution bar length changes when breakdown option is selected.

This happens because multi-line contribution bars are incorrectly
calculated for file formats. If a contribution bar is unable to fit
in the current line, a new line is added and the width of the new line
is subtracted from the previous contribution bar element. However, this
subtraction can lead to a negative number and it is left unchecked.
This will cause the contribution bar to be longer than expected because
the negative width was not accounted for (elements with negative widths
will just be rendered as having zero width).

Lets fix the bar width calculation by checking for negative widths,
and rectify it by removing the element with negative width and
subtracting that amount from the other remaining contribution bar
element.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#643] Fix GitBranch failure due to empty repos (#644)
commitResults.messageBody:
The application crashes when the analysis involves an empty
repository.

The causation of this is the GitBranch#getCurrentBranch method; it
splits the value returned by the `git branch`, which can be an empty
string when performed on an empty repository, and attempt to access the
second element of it which raise the ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException.

Let's fix this by returning a checked exception to ensure users of this
api handles this exception.

commitResults.messageTitle: DeveloperGuide: add setup instructions
Setup travis to execute test code
Travis: add files standardization tests
Fix file standardization violations
Checkstyle: temporary javadoc severity reduction
Checkstyle: fix some violations 1
Checkstyle: fix some violations 2
Checkstyle: fix some violations 3
Checkstyle: fix some violations 4
Checkstyle: fix some violations 5
Checkstyle: fix some violations 6
Checkstyle: fix some violations 7
Travis: add checkstyle to CI test
[#30] Report#Toolbar: rename Team to Repo/Branch (#422)
commitResults.messageBody:
In our tool bar, we use the term `Team` to define the group of authors
that are from the same repository and branch. 

However, the use of this term can cause confusion to users as it is not
a common terminology among the Git users.

To improve the clarity of our selectable options, let's rename the word
Team to Repo/Branch.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#554] Rename 'dashboard' instances to 'report' (#579)
commitResults.messageBody:
The term 'report' and 'dashboard' are used throughout RepoSense to
refer to the same thing, the result after running analysis.

However, users may not understand the subtle differences between
these two terms. Instead, using a single term would help in
standardization and comprehensibility.

Let's rename all usage of 'dashboard' instances to the term 'report'
instead, as standardized in #220.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#405] Code view: reset to top when loading new code view (#428)
commitResults.messageBody:
The code panel holds the scroll position of the previous view even
after loading the code of a new person.

This can cause inconvenience to the reviewers as they need to scroll
the panel back to the top after each review.

Let's reset the code panel back to the top when the content changes.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#396] Provide a link to repo even when not grouped by repo (#426)
commitResults.messageBody:
Link to the repository is only available in the chart view when the
`group by repo/branch` is selected, represented by an embedded
hyperlink in the group title.

This causes inconvenience to the users who want to visit the repository
when the authors are listed individually, as the link to repository
cannot be found. 

Let's move the hyperlink in the group title to the individual author's
code view, and also add a button next to every author's name in the
chart view, to ensure consistent navigability to author's repository.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#374] Add args to ignore standalone config in command line (#431)
commitResults.messageBody:
When running the analysis using the -repo(s) command, we will use the
standalone config settings in the repository, if it exists.

However, the author may simply want to run the analysis without
the interference of the standalone config.

Let's add a --ignore-standalone-config (-isac as alias) flag in
command line, to allow users to ignore the standalone config
in the repository for the -repo(s) command.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#350] [Enhancement] author-config.csv: make repo's location optional field  (#441)
commitResults.messageBody:
In the author-config.csv, each author must provide a location field,
which is mapped to the repository to be analyzed in repo-config.csv.

However, the user may want to analyze the contribution of an author for
all the repositories in repo-config.csv, and it is inconvenient for the
user to type it out for each repository.

Let's allow users to leave the location field empty in
author-config.csv, which will add this author to all the repositories
in repo-config.csv.

Things to note, if an author with empty location exist, all the repos
will not use the default all authors as this author with empty location
will beadded to all the repositories.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#481] Remove unused report folder (#489)
commitResults.messageBody:
The report folder in the project root seems to be unused.

Let's remove the unused folder keep the project clean.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#466] CodeView: give link to history and blame views of each file (#490)
commitResults.messageBody:
Reviewers may have the need to investigate on a file to see who else
has edited the same file, however, this feature is not available in the
code view.

Let's add direct links in the code view to visit the history view and
blame view of the files (on GitHub).

commitResults.messageTitle: [#534] Fix untouched code button failure (#536)
commitResults.messageBody:
The toggleNext() function were edited in #490 to limit the toggle
option to the path of the title.

However, as the untouched code button also taps on this function, it
has malfunctioned the show/hide untouched code capability.

Let's restore the toggleNext() to the state before #490, and changes
the way to this function is called at the title to perform the required
result in #490.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#523] build.gradle: Fix checkstyle plugin failure in JDK11 (#530)
commitResults.messageBody:
The `checkstyle` plugin of Gradle fails in JDK11.

The main reason is that, in JDK11, the `user.dir` cannot be reset by
gradle. Also, the `FileContentHolder` module is deprecated.

Let's add a variable suggested by Gradle to solve this problem.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#449, #479] ArgsParser: extract magic strings and follow a widely-used standard for CLI (#526)
commitResults.messageBody:
In ArgsParser, the string flags used for the CLI are magic strings
repeated in multiple places. Meanwhile, the standard of CLI argument
used does not follow a widely-used standard.

We should avoid the use of magic strings, instead defining them in a
central location. As RepoSense is designed for CLI usage, it is also
a good idea to follow a widely-used standard for CLI to match user
expectations. 

Let's define the magic strings in a central location as constants and
follow the GNU Coding Standard[1] for the CLI, using `--` prefix for
`long-named flags` and `-` for its equivalent `single-letter alias`.

[1] GNU Coding Standards: Command Line Interfaces
https://www.gnu.org/prep/standards/html_node/Command_002dLine-Interfaces.html

commitResults.messageTitle: README: add new project members (#582)
[#561] DashboardServer: Desktop#isDesktopSupported passes on headless systems (#580)
commitResults.messageBody:
`Desktop.isDesktopSupported()` is used in the DashboardServer to check
for the Desktop environment prior to the launching of dashboard.

However, in a headless system, this check will return true
irregardless, resulting in an uncaught run time exception to be thrown.

To ensure that this action is truly supported by the executing
environment, let's add an additional condition to ensure that the
instance supports browsing action.

commitResults.messageTitle: Checkstyle: update addresses of DTD files #586
commitResults.messageBody:
We are using the DTD files from http://checkstyle.sourceforge.net/
and http://puppycrawl.com/ in our config file of checkstyle.

However, due to security reason, checkstyle decided to remove DTDs from
above websites and ask users to use the DTD files from
https://checkstyle.org/[1].

Let's update the addresses of DTD files correspondingly.

As later version of the suppression DTD file has been released[2],
let's also update the DTD file to the latest version.

[1] Checkstyle removes DTDs from http://checkstyle.sourceforge.net:
checkstyle/checkstyle#6478

[2] Checkstyle Suppressions.xml example:
https://checkstyle.org/config_filters.html#SuppressionFilter_Examples

commitResults.messageTitle: [#510] Remove unused Checkstyle analysis feature (#597)
commitResults.messageBody:
The checkstyle analysis feature was added to the code base in the
early stage of RepoSense, when there was some hope of running static
analysis over the code written by authors of the repositories.

As this feature has not been used since early stages(v1.0), and it
is also not in our immediate plans anymore, leaving it will
unnecessarily complicate the codebase.

Let's clean up the code base by removing this unused checkstyle
analysis feature.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#590] Add default title and icon for RepoSense (#612)
commitResults.messageBody:
We do not have a title and icon set for the generated report.

This causes the title to be automatically set to the url of the page
instead, which does not provide any useful information to the user.

Let's add a default title and icon for the generated report.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#459] CLI: add args to choose any timezone (#496)
commitResults.messageBody:
The generated time shown in the report is in the timezone of SGT
(UTC+8).

Due to time differences, it is inconvenient for global users to use the
timezone of Singapore in their report.

Let's set the default timezone to the system's one, and add an argument
in the command line to allow the users to choose a timezone to use.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#588] CodeView: align the checkboxes (#589)
commitResults.messageBody:
After #532 , the name of the checkbox is changed from `mui-checkbox` to
`mui-checkbox--filetype`, causing an alignment problem with the
checkboxes.

Since this rename is meaningful, let's add another css part to ensure
that the checkboxes align.

Meanwhile, some of the indentation in #532 does not follow our
standard, let's update them as well.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#600] Integrate ci code coverage (#620)
commitResults.messageBody:
We do not have a Coverage Test because our coverage was low and
had quite a few architecture changes in the past.

Having a coverage test allows us to improve our testing with higher
revenue and lower costs. 

Let's integrate Coverage Test using Gradle Jacoco plugin and
codecov.io.

As this adds more tasks and configurations to already disordered
build.gradle file, let's also reorganize the file to have a consistent
line indentation of 4 spaces and systematic structure.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#619] Remove unused classes in functional code (#628)
commitResults.messageBody:
The MethodAnalyzer and MethodInfo classes were added to the
codebase in the early stage of RepoSense, when there was some
hope of identifying authors of methods of Java file. The
ConfigurationBuilder class was used by GitGrader which has been
remove from codebase and it is not used in the main code.

As these classes have not been used since early stages(v1.0), and they
are also not in our immediate plans anymore, leaving them will
unnecessarily complicate the codebase.

Let's clean up the code base by removing these unused classes.

commitResults.messageTitle: RepoConfigurationTest: relocate to reposense.model (#629)
commitResults.messageBody:
`RepoConfigurationTest` is under package ` reposense.parser`.

However, the class under test is `RepoConfiguration` which belongs to
the `reposense.model` package. Hence, it is not reasonable to put its
test file under a different package.

Let's move `RepoConfigurationTest` to `reposense.model` to 
solve the problem.

commitResults.messageTitle: Disable Codecov robot comment (#631)
commitResults.messageBody:
Codecov robot will post comments in each PR reporting the coverage diff
of the current PR.

As the coverage is shown in the PR status, this creates unnecessary noise.

Let's disable Codecov robot command by customizing codecov.yml.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#599] CodeView: fix `All` checkbox indication failure (#611)
commitResults.messageBody:
The `All` checkbox of file formats remains checked even after the user
have performed the deselection of other checkboxes. This is a bug as
the `All` checkbox should have unchecked itself automatically.

This bug originates from #487, where the author have accidentally split
selectFileFormat into two functions. It causes the status of
`All` checkbox gets updated as the separated function was not part of
any execution code.

It is also related to a bug where the `fileFormats` in the frontend
contain formats with 0 lines, which results in the formats displayed
may not be equal to the formats stored in `fileFormats`.

Additionally, the logic of the `All` checkbox is flawed. When the user
selects a checkbox after deselecting all of them, the checkbox will not
update itself correspondingly too.

To restore the intended functionality, let's revert the separation made
in #487 and correct the logic of the `All` checkbox.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#581] CodeView#filter: add interactive selection switch (#608)
commitResults.messageBody:
The filter selection's radio button serves nothing more than an "indicator".
Changing option doesn't do anything until the corresponding controls are
modified.

It is redundant and inconvenient for users to manually switch the selection.

Instead of disabling the deselected option, let's allow interaction switch
the selection.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#503] CLI: add --version tag to show version of RepoSense (#565)
commitResults.messageBody:
Users may want to figure out whether the jar file they download is
the correct version of RepoSense they want to use.

The users cannot verify it because we do not have a 'version' tag,
and the generated report do not contain such information.

Let's add a -version tag to show the version of jar file of RepoSense,
and include it in the generated report.

The version can be passed in to RepoSense using -Pversion for both run
and shadowJar. Otherwise, latest git tag will be used instead.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#621] LogsManager: shift the log file to output folder (#632)
commitResults.messageBody:
The log file of RepoSense is stored at a fixed folder `logs` in the
current working directory.

In the event of a bug investigation, it would be more useful if the
log file is tagged along with the generated report.

Let's have the log file generated together in the designed output
folder.

The side effect of this PR is that the log message generated in
ArgsParser#parse() will not be logged in the file, as the
output folder is not decided yet.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#678] Report: use development version of vue.js (#679)
commitResults.messageBody:
Vue has a plugin for Chrome and Firefox for debugging Vue.js
applications. However, the minified version of Vue in our frontend is a
production version, so we are unable to use the plugin to debug
RepoSense report.

Let's use the development version of Vue.js to allow the use of Vue
developer tool.

README.md: update product name to RepoSense
