Reorganize UserGuide.md to improve the flow (#344)
commitResults.messageBody:
In the User Guide, sections relevant to those using RepoSense on a single repo
are scattered.

Let's reorganize the flow to bring such sections to the top of the document.
At the same time, let us reduce forward referencing and duplication so that the
User Guide can be read mostly top to bottom in logical order.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#745] Toolbar: edit flexbox properties (#768)
commitResults.messageBody:
The toolbar does not adjust to changes in window or pane width.

Under certain widths, the `search` field is not visible.

Let's edit the flexbox properties of the toolbar to allow its elements
to shrink and wrap to occupy more rows when the window or pane width 
is decreased.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#705] Log: distinct warning and error messages (#794)
commitResults.messageBody:
Messages of different severity are outputed in similar format, without
any form of distinction.

This creates difficulty for our users to distinguish messages of
different severity from the logs. Moreover, messages of higher severity
often contains important info which may requires user's action and
shouldn't be left unnoticed.

Let's make these messages more distinct by inserting a highlighted
status tag e.g. `[ERROR]` before the message.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#753] Display individuals' contribution (#762)
commitResults.messageBody:
Contribution is shown only for each group as a whole.

While it is possible to view the contribution based on each chart by 
hovering over the contribution bar, this requires extra work by the
user. It will be more user-friendly if the contribution can be viewed
on the page itself.

Let's display the contribution for each chart in the chart title.
This information is shown using the same style as the group's total 
contribution.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#661] Change chart title format (#802)
commitResults.messageBody:
The chart title uses underscores to separate `org`, `repo` and
`branch`. Furthermore, `displayName` is used for both the chart title
and repo analysis output folder name.

`org`, `repo` and `branch` might have underscores in them, making it
difficult to discern each term. Using a single parameter displayName
to represent both the output folder name and the chart title would
constrain us to not use /. This has shown that the output folder name
and the chart title have little compatibility, and difficulty in coming
up with a coherent format.

Let's use a separate variable, `outputFolderName`, for the out folder
name so that a different format, `org/repo[branch]`, can be used for
the chart title.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#98] Implement a logger (#123)
commitResults.messageBody:
Currently, all the unnecessary information - not concerning the user
is being printed on console. 

Let's implement a logger to display only relevant information on the
console and save the rest of it on an external log file.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#139] Clean up the logger output  (#145)
commitResults.messageBody:
Currently, the logger shows a lot of extra information in console which
might not be useful for the user.

Let's configure the logger to show only the useful information to the
user.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#132] Configure gradle to run with arguments (#136)
commitResults.messageBody:
Our application requires input arguments to run from the console. 
However, without configuring the IDE or without the jar file, it is 
not possible to pass input arguments for the application to run.

Let's configure gradle to run with input parameters to make the
application independent of platforms.

commitResults.messageTitle: FileUtil: add zip function for offline preview (#152)
commitResults.messageBody:
To view the dashboard, we need to run a local server as the
security in web browsers does not allow it to traverse the directories
on local machine.

Let's zip all the necessary json files together to make our
application compatible with all the browsers and bypass the need to run
the application on local server.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add functionality to start the web server to display the dashboard (#211)
commitResults.messageBody:
To display the dashboard, user has to generate the report and manually
open the index.html and upload the zip file (for chrome and safari
users).

Lets give users an option to start the server and display the dashboard
for the specified report directory using the jar.

commitResults.messageTitle: Include timestamp footer in the dashboard (#235)
commitResults.messageBody:
When reviewing multiple dashboards, it may be possible that user gets
confused with the version of the dashboard.

To assist the user, ensure that he/she is viewing the correct version,
let's include a generated timestamp in the footer of the dashboard.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#188] Dashboard: code panel graphical improvement (#257)
[#170] CodeView: add selection to filter files by format (#448)
commitResults.messageBody:
When viewing the files changed by an author, all the files will be 
listed. There is no way to filter out irrelevant files.

Users may want to view files of certain file extensions.

Let's 
* add checkboxes for users to select/unselect their file extensions 
and view files of the checked extensions
* select-all checkbox if users want to check all of the file extensions
* LOC count is also shifted beside the checkboxes

Future improvement: There is some lagging as the number of file 
extensions selected is increased, mostly due to DOM update time.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#473] CodeView: fix mismatch of displayed file content (#477)
commitResults.messageBody:
When a file extension is unselected, the file content is not always updated 
despite a change in filename.

This is due to vuejs reusing the DOM for each file as a performance optimization. 

Let's add a key attribute to each file, so that vuejs can track every file correctly 
with proper reusing of the DOM.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#501] ChartView: apply case-insensitive sorting sequence to `Author Name` (#488)
commitResults.messageBody:
ChartView's sorting option sorts the author's name in a
case-sensitive manner.

By default, the display name in the report takes on the Author's GitHub
ID. As GitHub ID is case insensitively unique, there is no apparent
benefit in treating the uppercase and lowercase text as distinct.

Let's apply case-insensitive sorting sequence for the author's name
instead.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#521] CodeView: Collapse/Expand All button not updated correctly after hiding all files (#529)
commitResults.messageBody:
If the select-all box for file formats in the code panel is unchecked,
the 'Collapse/Expand All' button will change to become 'Expand All' as
all files are hidden. However, when the select-all box is checked
again, all the files rendered will be expanded, but the
'Collapse/Expand All' button will remain at 'Expand All'.

This is due to files being automatically expanded when they are
rendered, after we check any of the file format checkboxes.

Let's update the 'Collapse/Expand All' button to also track files
that are newly rendered that are expanded whenever a file format 
checkbox is clicked.

commitResults.messageTitle: ChartView: update code for list-rendering (#513)
commitResults.messageBody:
During list rendering, `v-for` is used with `v-if` which can increase
the file processing time, due to additional checks.

Let's follow the Vue style guide[1] by replacing these instances with
computed properties, where necessary. Data is only updated when
changed, instead of being generated every time.

[1]: Vue style guide for avoiding use of v-if with for
https://vuejs.org/v2/style-guide/#Avoid-v-if-with-v-for-essential

commitResults.messageTitle: [#465] Url: bookmark opened code view (#524)
commitResults.messageBody:
Our report's url changes along with the state of the dashboard as a
mechanism to allow users to easily revisit her last view as well as
easily be shared with other people.

However, this was only limited to the chart view configuration, nothing
of the code view were part of the state being saved.

To allow users to easily restore their last reviewed code view, let's
also encode any opened code view into the url.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#543] RampChart: add group by authors option (#570)
commitResults.messageBody:
Users are only allowed to group the ramp charts by repository.

While grouping by repository allows users to have a rough comparison of
contributions between authors of the same repository, it does not
provide any insight into an author's contribution data across all
repositories he has contributed to.

Let's add the grouping of authors as an option for users to select, and
this can work towards the goal of having a toolbar[1] at the top of the
report.

[1]: Sorting options graphical goal:
https://github.com/orgs/reposense/teams/devs/discussions/1

commitResults.messageTitle: [#398] GitLog: handle paths in config that exist outside the repo (#592)
commitResults.messageBody:
If users try to put folders existing outside of the git repository 
inside the ignore-glob-list, it will lead to a RuntimeException as the
`git log` command fails.

Let's check that the path is inside the repository, before writing it
into the ignore-glob-list and running the `git log` command.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#601] ChartView: improve the sort controls (#618)
commitResults.messageBody:
When the ramp charts are grouped together, the sorting is only
performed within the group. This may differs from the expectation of
some users, who may wish to sort them by groups e.g. to list them
accordingly to the group's combined contribution. 

Also, the `reverse` option is not well-presented nor intuitive to the
users enough to understand that it is meant to reverses the sorted
listing. 

Let's fix the mentioned problems by adding another drop-down select
menu to allow the sorting of groups, and include direction arrows in
menu items to replace the need of reverse option.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#463] ChartView: add contribution and variance to `sort groups by` (#639)
commitResults.messageBody:
Contribution and variance options are not available in `sort groups by`
when the `group by` option is selected.

Users may wish to sort the groups with this 2 options, ranking them in
terms of activity level, so that they can pay more attention to the
most/least achievers.

Let's allow the sorting of groups, by these 2 options, be available at
all times.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#393] Remove undefined parameter in the URL (#432)
commitResults.messageBody:
window.location.hash is initially empty and calling split('&')
creates an array containing a single empty string.

When trying to split this empty string into a key and value,
the result is an empty key and and undefined value which
causes =undefined to appear in the URL.

Let's add a check to ensure that the key is not empty to
prevent this empty string from being included when adding
key value pairs to window.hashParams. This also prevents
any empty keys introduced as a result of user error, perhaps
from editing the URL manually, from being processed.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#316] Split RepoConfiguration into more classes (#425)
commitResults.messageBody:
RepoConfiguration has many analysis parameters and as more are added,
it becomes larger and harder to maintain.

Let's delegate some of the parameters to their own classes, this includes
Location, Format and Commit.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#107] Shift from File to Path class (#114)
commitResults.messageBody:
java.nio.file.Path is able to do everything java.io.File can and
generally in a better way.This is supported by the document posted on
the website:
https://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/essential/io/legacy.html.

Let's move towards to using Path as a replacement to File whenever we
can for better exception handling and OS invariant coding.

commitResults.messageTitle: Improve performance (#126)
commitResults.messageBody:
The analyzing of contribution for each file in the program is very
slow due to several factors:
1. The `git blame` process produces a lot of unnecessary line
information, causing a large amount of unnecessary time spent reading
I/O. 
2. StreamGobbler uses String concatenation when reading from process
InputStream, which is polynomial in time based on the number of lines.

Let's improve performance of the program and functional test by:
1. Filter the `git blame` process output using `findstr` in Windows OS
or `grep` for other OS, thus having a smaller I/O to read.
2. Change StreamGobbler to read directly from InputStream instead of
using a BufferedReader, and use StringBuilder instead of String
concatenation.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#92] FileInfo: date range does not affect code contribution (#137)
commitResults.messageBody:
The date range entered in the CLI does not affect the total code
contribution collated in the FileInfo.

This is because the git blame command used is analyzing the entire
commit history, instead of only the commits within the date range
specified.

Let's update the CommandRunner#blameRaw(String, String) git blame
command to specify the date range of commits to analyze, if specified.
Let's also update RepoAnalyzer#analyzeAuthorship(RepoConfiguration) to
checkout to the latest commit before analyzing the files.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#69] Architecture: apply separation of concern to multiple classes (#147)
commitResults.messageBody:
Classes such as GitBlamer have multiple responsibilities,
generating the FileInfo, analyzing of the git blame results and setting
authorship of each line in the file.

This leads to lots of coupling due to violation of Single Responsibility
Principle.

Let's split the responsibility of generation and analyze of authorship
and commit info into different classes.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#131] Redirect functional test to use testrepo (#133)
commitResults.messageBody:
Functional is performing the test on repositories that are beyond our
control.

This means that if the repositories' owners make any changes to their
repository, it will affect our test results.

Let's use the state-preserved, forked repositories under our
organization instead.

commitResults.messageTitle: Update developer guide (#151)
commitResults.messageBody:
After PRs #95 #99 #111 and #147, the Developer Guide is now out of
date with the code base's architecture.

The dependency on git written also does not specify the version
required.

Let's update the Developer Guide with the architecture changes,
add a diagram of the proposed final architecture and update the
version dependency on git.

commitResults.messageTitle: Fix link in README and dependency notes in UserGuide (#175)
commitResults.messageBody:
Due to renaming of developer_guide.md to DeveloperGuide.md 
and user_guide.md to UserGuide.md, the links in README.md leading
to those two documents are now broken.

Let's fix those broken links.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#177] Add more default file types to analyze (#178)
commitResults.messageBody:
RepoSense only tracks '.java' and '.adoc' file types for analyse.

This may not be sufficient for visualization as not many other projects that
are not mainly coded in Java or use asciidoctor for their documents.

Let's include more file types by default in the analysis.

commitResults.messageTitle: UserGuide: update images of the new UI (#179)
commitResults.messageBody:
After the UI revamp for v1.1 release, the images of the dashboard
in UserGuide.md is now outdated.

Let's update the images in UserGuide.md to reflect the new dashboard
UI.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#182, #183] FileInfoExtractor: decode non-UTF-8 characters (#180)
commitResults.messageBody:
FileInfoExtractor#generateFileInfo(String, String)
and FileInfoAnalyzer#isReused(String,String) use
Files#newBufferedReader(Path) to construct the BufferedReader for
reading of files.

This constructed BufferedReader uses the default UTF-8 Charset[1]
and a default CharsetDecoder[2] to decode the bytes
read from files into Strings.[3]

As some files being analyzed may contain special characters that are
not from the UTF-8 character set[3], it causes the BufferedReader to
throw a java.nio.charset.MalformedInputException.

As a result, it creates an incomplete FileInfo in
FileInfoExtractor#generateFileInfo(String, String) process, which causes the
program to crash when analysing the file in 
FileInfoAnalyzer#aggregateBlameAuthorInfo(RepoConfiguration, FileInfo).
This is due to the number of lines analyzed in git blame being greater than
the number of lines inside FileInfo. It will also cause the analysis of
some white-listed files to be skipped inside
FileInfoAnalyzer#isReused(String,String).

Let's update FileInfoExtractor#generateFileInfo(String, String)
and FileInfoAnalyzer#isReused(String,String) to construct the
BufferedReader with an java.io.FileReader instead.

The java.io.FileReader extends java.io.InputStreamReader,
which use the same default UTF-8 Charset. However, it will call 
StreamDecoder#forInputStreamReader(InputStream, Object, CharsetDecoder)
, which will set the CharsetDecoder to replace the malformed input
instead of throwing an error[5], thus allowing the FileInfo to be
constructed with the correct number of lines.

[1] Javadocs of Charset:
https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/nio/charset/Charset.html

[2] Javadocs of CharsetDecoder:
https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/nio/charset/CharsetDecoder.html

[3] Source code of Files.newBufferedReader(Path, Charset):
http://hg.openjdk.java.net/jdk8u/jdk8u/jdk/file/be30cb2a3088/src/share/classes/java/nio/file/Files.java#l2780

[4] Example of a file with non-UTF-8 characters inside:
https://github.com/CS2103JAN2018-F11-B4/main/blob/master/collated/functional/ZhangYijiong.md

[5] Source code of StreamDecoder setting malformed input to be replaced:
http://hg.openjdk.java.net/jdk8/jdk8/jdk/file/687fd7c7986d/src/share/classes/sun/nio/cs/StreamDecoder.java#l230

commitResults.messageTitle: build.gradle: fix output location for jar file (#208)
[#206] Fix different branches of same repository using same display name (#207)
commitResults.messageBody:
In the .csv config file, we may supply the same organization
and repository, but different branches for different authors.

In CsvParser, these will be separated into two different
RepoConfigurations, and analysis will be run separately, generating
separate reports.

However, as we set the display name for each RepoConfiguration to
only be the 'organization' and 'repository', these different
RepoConfigurations will override each other's report as they are
being generated into the same folder.

Let's update RepoConfiguration's display name to include the
branch as well. This will cause the report to be generated into a
different folder for different branches.

commitResults.messageTitle: Remove copy move detection for CommandRunner#blameRaw (#212)
commitResults.messageBody:
The git blame command in CommandRunner#blameRaw(String, String)
uses copy and move detection[1] for its line authorship analysis.

These may cause an author's commit contribution and
his line contribution count on the dashboard to be inconsistent,
as a the author may have copied or moved lines from another
author, which will cause those lines to be authored to the other
author instead.

If necessary, users may use collate if they wish to identify if
certain codes belong to them, instead of us trying
to identify the 'original' author by ourselves.

Let's remove the copy and move detection in
CommandRunner#blameRaw(String, String) git blame command.

[1]: Docs on the git blame copy and move detection:
https://git-scm.com/docs/git-blame#git-blame--Mltnumgt

commitResults.messageTitle: [#203] Authorship: incorrect line authorship when analyzing date range (#205)
commitResults.messageBody:
When a date range is supplied, the FileInfoAnalyzer will only
git blame on the range of commits that fall within the given
date range.

This may cause the authorship of certain lines that have not
been touched at all during the date range to be incorrectly
authored to a random author that commited in that date range.

Let's update the git blame command to run the git blame from
initial to the latest commit of that date range. In addition, let's
also update FileInfoExtractor to only track lines that were added
within the date range, and add them into the final authorship count.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#215] Extracting info from git diff is not working as expected (#216)
commitResults.messageBody:
FileInfoExtractor#getFilePathFromDiffPattern(String) checks
for the group pattern '+++ b/path/to/file'
within the git diff result in order to get the file path.

However, when a new and also empty file is added in between the
commit range to analysis, the file will appear in the git diff result,
but since there are no lines to display, the above group does not
get printed, thus 
FileInfoExtractor#getFilePathFromDiffPattern(String) is unable
to match the pattern, causing the program to crash.

Let's add a check to skip these new and empty files in 
the git diff result, since an empty file has no lines to 
attribute any contribution.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#218] Add support for file exclusion patterns (#229)
commitResults.messageBody:
RepoSense only accepts an inclusive list of file formats to analyze.

However, users may wish to specifically exclude analyze of some
files or folders, such as large data files or test folders, as they may
not be meaningful to analyze.

Let's add back-end support to exclude analyzing of files of specified
glob patterns, which can be done in git log by using pathspec[1].

[1] Intro to Git's pathspec:
https://kgrz.io/git-intro-to-pathspec.html

commitResults.messageTitle: [#234] Modify analysis of files and commits to be at Author level (#236)
commitResults.messageBody:
RepoSense only uses Repoconfiguration for the
analysis of files and commits, causing these analysis
to be on the repo level.

As we will be implementing configuration settings for each
individual author of a repo, the analysis of files and commits
will also need to be on the author level.

Let's update the analysis of files and commits to be on the
author level.

commitResults.messageTitle: Fix empty ramps when overriding RepoConfiguration (#243)
commitResults.messageBody:
When a repo has a _reposense/config.json configuration file,
the RepoConfiguration will be reset to the new config.json file,
and all authors are reset as well.

However, these reset authors does not have their author aliases
or ignore glob list set inside them. This may cause some of the
commit info to be missing as we are filtering commits by author
names and aliases.

Let's fix this by updating the
RepoConfiguration#update(StandAloneConfig) to set the
author aliases and ignore glob list for each author inside the
config.json file.

commitResults.messageTitle: Update data for testrepo-Delta (#247)
commitResults.messageBody:
testrepo-Delta contains its own standalone configuration, and it has
been updated with the author aliases.

Let's update our expected results in the unit and functional test to
match the recent update.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#262] Ignore glob list does not propagate to code view (#265)
commitResults.messageBody:
Each author has their own ignoreGlobList, which should ignore
any of their contributions to any files within that glob list.

However, while the commits information are correctly ignored,
the authorship information is not, as some files that should be
in the glob list still appeared for the author's contribution.
This is due to AnnotatorAnalyzer not ignoring the files in the
glob list, and overriding the original git blame results.

Let's resolve this by updating AnnotatorAnalyzer to remove
author contribution if the file being analyzed is inside their
glob list.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#274] Fix repo-config.csv ignoreGlobList not affecting contribution (#280)
commitResults.messageBody:
After #238, the config files now are split to repo-config.csv and
author-config.csv, allowing users to set author and repo level
configurations.

However, even when a ignoreGlobList is specified inside the
repo-config.csv, it does not affect the contribution, and the files
specified were still being analyzed.

This is due to Author not updating its ignoreGlobMatcher
after we append the repo level ignoreGlobList to the
author's own list.

Let's update Author to call its updateIgnoreGlobMatcher()
method whenever appendIgnoreGlobList(List<String>) is called.
Let's also update the functional test repo-config.csv and
author-config.csv to contain some ignoreGlobLists for testing.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#299] Fix error matching file path pattern inside file diff result (#300)
commitResults.messageBody:
FileInfoExtractor#getFilePathFromDiffPattern(String) checks
for the group pattern '+++ b/path/to/file'
within the git diff result in order to get the file path.

However, when a file is renamed without changing any of its
content in between the commit range to analysis, the file will
appear in the git diff result, but since there are no lines to display,
the above group does not get printed, thus 
FileInfoExtractor#getFilePathFromDiffPattern(String) is unable
to match the pattern, causing the program to crash.

Let's add a check to skip these renamed but untouched files in 
the git diff result, since an untouched file has no lines to 
attribute any contribution.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#301] Hotfix: report folder not generated when failed to analyze repo (#302)
commitResults.messageBody:
When we fail to clone/checkout a config's repository, we will
skip analyzing that repository, thus not generating its report folder.

However, as the config is still inside the config list, we will still add
that 'failed' config into summary.json. This will cause the dashboard
to crash as it tries to load a report folder which does not exist.

Let's update ReportGenerator to generate the report folder with
'empty' reports when failing to clone/checkout the repository, so as
to allow the dashboard to be viewed, and also allow the user to identify
errors in which repository config info given.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#246] Add support for repo-level commit exclusion (#261)
commitResults.messageBody:
User may sometimes wish to ignore some 'ugly' commits
made that will distort the dashboard's rampchart statistics.

To allow this, let's add support for repo-level commit
exclusions.

commitResults.messageTitle: Clean up build.gradle (#309)
commitResults.messageBody:
build.gradle contains some unused dependencies, inconsistent styles,
outdated version plugins etc.

Let's fix them.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#85] Rename functional to systemtest (#306)
commitResults.messageBody:
Functional folder is a skeleton of an end-to-end testing infrastructure.

However the name is not intuitive enough to imply it so. Also, the functional
test is placed in a separate package of the 'src' module instead of the 'test' 
module, making IntelliJ unable to find the classes and resources to run it.

Let's rename functional to system test.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#340] Allow non-alpha-numeric characters in GitHub usernames (#347)
commitResults.messageBody:
The Author class restricts the github id and author names to only contain
alphanumeric characters, plus some other symbols, for security purposes as
this values are used inside the OS terminal.

As we are allowed to change out git author name to be anything as it
does not have any restrictions, having this restrictions for our Author
class will prevent some users from using our app to analyze their repo
if the author name they wish to use contain non alphanumeric characters.

Also, special non-UTF-8 characters may also be used for the author name,
which may cause MalformedInputException[1] when trying to read the
author-config.csv file.

As the --author param field of the git log command uses regex pattern
to perform the author filtration, we can swap out any of these computer
symbols which may have different uses in the OS terminal into a . period
instead to indicate any character instead, allowing us to still get the correct
author filter without conflicting with the OS terminal. However, this may
cause the accuracy of the analysis to be reduced if there are multiple authors
with very similar names in the repo.

Let's
- remove validation of github id and names in the Author class
- add a method in StringUtil to swap computer symbols in the author
name to the . period
- add a note in the UserGuide warning users who have author names
that are very similar and have symbols
- update the CsvParser to use the java.io BufferedReader constructor for
reading of the csv files instead to allow non-UTF-8 characters.

[1]: Similar issue when reading files previously resolved
https://github.com/reposense/RepoSense/commit/1f222c0fd93fd8c5399a27c18aa03c03871f7cee

commitResults.messageTitle: [#341] Show only authors who have contributed during analysis period (#349)
commitResults.messageBody:
When no author details is specified for a repo to analyze, all authors who
have contributed to the repo will be analyzed by default, even if a date
range is specified where some of the authors did not contribute in.

As users are only interested in the analysis within that date range if they
specify one, having all the other authors who did not contribute in that
date range also listed out will lead to unnecessary usage of time generating
the report, and fill the dashboard with unnecessary information as those authors
will have zero contribution, increasing its memory usage.

Let's update the analysis to only consider the authors within date range
if no author details is specified.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#357] FileInfoExtractor: use cleaner alternative to extract code change (#361)
commitResults.messageBody:
FileInfoExtractor#getEditedFileInfos(...) first checks for each file
whether they in a blacklist of 'uncommon' file changes which does not
follow the line patterns that we check for, and skips those files as they
are all unchanged files that does not have any difference to check for.

As there are many of such 'uncommon' file changes, some of these changes
may not have been added in our blacklist yet, which may cause the program
to crash unexpectedly, e.g #215 #300 #356.

Instead of trying to find out each of this 'uncommon' file changes and
blacklisting each 1 of them, it is easier and cleaner to whitelist only
those files that have valid diff file changes which follow the line patterns
we are checking for.

Let's change the blacklist for valid diff files to be a whitelist instead,
and check for the exception if this file is deleted.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#370] Fix uncaught InvalidPathException due to Illegal char <:> in file name (#371)
commitResults.messageBody:
Windows disallows certain characters for the file names, such as `/\:*?"<>|`,
while other OSes like Linux allows almost any characters for their file names.
This may result in some files with such `banned` characters in the repository
to not be copied/cloned into a local copy for Windows OS.

As we use the `git diff` command to find file differences for analyzing
repositories with a date range, such files with `banned` characters may appear
in the `git diff` result, which result in an InvalidPathException being thrown
when we try to create a Path to this file name, which is invalid in Windows.
This causes the program to crash as the exception is not handled anywhere.

Let's update FileInfoExtractor to handle files with invalid file names by
skipping those files.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#297] UserGuide: add FAQ section to address common problems (#494)
commitResults.messageBody:
Our UserGuide does not have a FAQ section.

Let's add a FAQ section in our UserGuide to address common questions
and issues, allowing users troubleshoot them themselves.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#546] FAQ: add another entry to propose email as alternative to GitHub ID (#568)
commitResults.messageBody:
In the UserGuide FAQ section, we mention that commit contribution
may not appear in the ramp chart if the user did not associate the
correct author name aliases to their GitHub ID, and to double check
their author name aliases.

After #493 though, RepoSense allows user to associate their GitHub
email to their GitHub ID as well, which is more accurate as it is a
fixed value, compared to author name aliases which can have many
different values depending on their local git settings and on different
machines. As such, it is better to ask users to use email instead of
author name aliases if they face such problems of their contribution
not being tracked by RepoSense.

Let's update FAQ to propose email as an alternative to associate to the
user's GitHub ID instead.

The command given in the `A Note About Git Author Name` is not
exactly accurate, as it only changes the git author name settings for
future initiated or cloned git repositories, but not for the current
git repository, which is what most users who are reading the FAQ would
want.

Let's also update the `A Note About Git Author Name` section to
include the correct command for changing the git author name settings
for the current git repository as well.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#444] UserGuide: fix typing error in `until` parameter example (#439)
commitResults.messageBody:
In `Customize Using Command Line Parameters` section of the User Guide,
the example for `until` parameter has been mistakenly given as `-since
01/10/2017`.

Let's fix this typo in the User Guide given example.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#474] Format: add 'txt' format to list of default formats (#475)
commitResults.messageBody:
Format#DEFAULT_FORMAT_STRINGS contains a list of common file extensions
within git repositories, which RepoSense will use to run the analysis by default
if no formats is given by the user.

However, this list does not contain the `txt` file extension, which is
also another commonly used file extension in git repositories.

For user's convenience, let's add the `txt` file extension to the list
of default format strings as well.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#447] CommitInfoAnalyzer: handle empty commit message (#440)
commitResults.messageBody:
We analyze the raw commit history to obtain information, such as
author, hash, date, message, insertion, deletion etc, about the
commit. The raw data undergoes splitting in order to obtain internal
conceptual representation. However, in the event of encountering a
commit with empty messages, the last index of split elements would be
missing and cause an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundException to be thrown. 

Although, by default, git does not allow empty commit message but this
behavior can be override by this command `git commit
--allow-empty-message`. Also, lightweight IDEs like Visual Studio Code
do allow users to commit without any message by accident.

To prevent breakage due to these corner cases, let's perform an index
check on the elements to avoid RepoSense crash due to the uncaught
exception.

Additional info:
A corner test case on this is included. It is made on the
empty-commit-message branch of testrepo-Alpha.

When committing changes on the Visual Studio Code, if only white spaces
were entered in commit message box, the IDE will commit the changes
without a message.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#380] Prevent generate FileInfo from directory with valid name (#511)
commitResults.messageBody:
RepoSense uses a list of file format as a whitelist to
filter files for analysis.

However, we use `String#endsWith` to test if both directories and
file's name is inside this whitelist to run the git-blame analysis.
Directories that are named with a file format inside this whitelist
are also added into the analysis, which causes RepoSense to crash as
git-blame fails when it is executed on a directory.

Let's fix this bug by excluding directories from the whitelist test.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#392] Show a 'loading...' message while loading the report for the first time (#498)
commitResults.messageBody:
RepoSense needs to load the resource files before it can generate
the dashboard, which can take a significant amount of time if the
resource files given are large.

However, RepoSense remains on the initial page, with the option to
upload a zip file, even after it has started loading these resource
files. This can be misleading to users as they may think they have
selected the wrong file and need to upload it again.

There is also no indication given if an invalid zip file was given,
which may make users wait indefinitely for the dashboard to load when
it won't.

Let's implement a loading page to inform the user that the application
is loading and a pop-up to inform the user if an invalid zip file is
given.

commitResults.messageTitle: Make center divider adjustable #403 (#418)
commitResults.messageBody:
RepoSense has a code panel and summary panel, each occupies
half of the screen. However, the code panel width cannot be resized.

Enabling resizing of the code panel will allow user to adjust it to
their comfort.

Let's have an adjustable code panel by dragging the width of the panel.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#519] Update JavaScript dependencies used in the frontend (#525)
commitResults.messageBody:
The frontend depends on various JavaScript libraries,
namely, vuejs and highlightjs, which are often updated
with improvements and fixes.

Let's update the JavaScript dependencies to the latest
versions, so that the frontend performs optimally.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#508] GitBlame: RuntimeError when analyzing branch name that is within whitelisted format (#535)
commitResults.messageBody:
When generating authorship report, RepoSense checks all the files
and directories in the repository by listing all of those from the
repository root.

This also includes the .git directory that contains all of the
repository's metadata files, and RepoSense will throw RuntimeError
if it encounters a branch name that matches any of the file format
whitelist.

However, as the git metadata files are not contributions made by
authors to the git repository, it is not necessary to traverse into
this directory and analyze of those files.

Let's fix this issue by excluding .git directory from file analysis
during authorship report generation.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#407] CodeView: give additional sorting options (#445)
commitResults.messageBody:
Files in the code view are automatically sorted by LoC.

While this helps reviewers to quickly locate the authors' top
contributed files, some may prefer looking through the files in other
hierarchical order.

Let's add sorting selection in the code view, allow users to
sort the files in different order (file name, file type or file path),
catering to the need of diversified users.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#542] Report: fix page unresponsive when loading repos with huge date gap (#596)
commitResults.messageBody:
RepoSense is unresponsive if we load many repos
with huge date gap, making it nearly unusable.

This is caused by the report generated having a lot of
empty commits per day, in which the frontend needs to
sift through to display the report.

Let's fix this issue by removing all those empty commits,
including only commits that are necessary.

commitResults.messageTitle: Checkstyle: increase severity of all existing rules #624 (#626)
commitResults.messageBody:
RepoSense has various coding style rules which are enforced by
Checkstyle for the Java codebase.

However, some of those rules only generate warning and not error,
which will still pass the CI and allow some coding style violation
to slip through.

Let's fix this by setting all the violations for the coding style
rules to error instead.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#518] RampChart: show up to report generation date, not last commit date (#539)
commitResults.messageBody:
In the UI, the user can choose the date range to show the report, which
is set to be until the date of the most recent commit, if no `--until`
flag is given.

However, the report may be generated at a date beyond the most recent
commit, and users would want to view all contributions up to the
report generation date instead.

Let's fix this bug by showing up until the report generation date in
the UI instead.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#607] summary.json: move sinceDate and untilDate become direct element (#615)
commitResults.messageBody:
summary.json has multiple identical sinceDate and untilDate
in each repo that is analyzed, which is redundant.

This is caused by sinceDate and untilDate being instance variable
of RepoConfiguration.

Let's rectify this problem by moving sinceDate and untilDate
out of RepoConfiguration into SummaryReportJson.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#21] Ramp chart: optimize vertical space (#109)
commitResults.messageBody:
Let's increase readability by updating the template to display
the contribution line of the different users more prominently.

commitResults.messageTitle: Fix dashboard padding function (#187)
commitResults.messageBody:
When displaying contributors with no commit history, the dashboard will
crash and stop rendering ramp charts for subsequent repositories.

This is caused by the padding of the ramp charts. The padding is added
to the ramp chart to align the charts across different users and
projects.

The amount of padding required is calculated from the `sinceDate` of
the first and last date entry of the user. This becomes problematic
when the user have no date entries at all, causing the system to run
into problem, and hence, skipping the ramp chart generation for the
particular project.

To fix this, let's alter the padding function to take into the edge
case of a empty date range, and artifically fill up the whole timeline
with generated empty dates.

commitResults.messageTitle: Remove generated template files from source code (#195)
commitResults.messageBody:
Since the dashboard revamp in v1.1, `template` no longer contains the
source of the dashboard. Instead, the source files are contained in
`frontend/src`, andcompiled into the corresponding `html` and `css`
files.

As good practice, these generated template files shouldn't be track.
Let's include the generation of all these template files in the gradle
build process instead.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#197, #201] Fix ramp chart positioning (#198)
commitResults.messageBody:
When the dashboard loads two projects of different date range, some of
the dashboard attributes will be messed up and this affects the
rendering of the ramp charts.

More specifically, the `sliceWidth` and `sliceCount` will be affected
by the date range and will cause the dashboard to incorrectly "thinks"
that it has more slices then it actually does, and hence causing it to
be incorrectly displayed squashed up together.

Let's remove the attributes in `v_summary` and generate the width and
position of the slices from the actual array of slices instead.

commitResults.messageTitle: Dashboard: remove navigation bar (#171)
commitResults.messageBody:
After the removal of the feature to support multiple reports, the
navigation bar contains only the reposense logo.

The bar now plays only an aesthetic role and has no functional purpose,
which is a waste of vertical space.

Similarly the filters on the summary tab could be more concisely
displayed to fully utilize the vertical space.

Let's make the necessary UI changes to improve vertical space usage.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#156] Dashboard: synchronize code panel display name (#164)
commitResults.messageBody:
The dashboard's overview displays the DisplayName as specified in the CSV
config file while the side panel displays the gitHub ID instead.

This may cause confusion to users as the display name and for overview and the
side panel is different.

Let's update the code panel to show the the same display name as overview.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#214] Fix code panel not showing the correct files (#168)
commitResults.messageBody:
When switching to display another author's code contribution, some of
the code panel's ui elements continue to display old data.

To prevent that from happening, let's tag the `v_authorship` module
with a key which forces vue to re-render `v_summary` as a new instance
with a fresh set of data.

commitResults.messageTitle: Dashboard: determine date range only after all repo data are loaded (#227)
commitResults.messageBody:
The dashboard as of v1.1.1 is loaded dynamically after each
`commits.json` is loaded.

If the filter date range is not defined, the range will be determined
by the first and last commits of that particular repository. This start
and end dates will then be set as the filter dates to be used for later
rendering of the other repositories.

However, this leads to a problem when the repositories are of a
different date range, if the earlier repository is loaded first, the
date range will not be able to display the ramps in the later
repository, vice versa.

To fix this issue, let's only determine the date ranges after all the
`commits.json` of the repositories is loaded.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#223] Dashboard: sort by authors by name within repo  (#233)
commitResults.messageBody:
The current dashboard as of v1.1.2 sorts the users in the repository
by the number of contributions they have made for the project in that
time period.

This however puts an unnecessary focus on the contribution LoC which
may not be a true reflection of the users' contribution. 

Let's change the default view to sort the users by their names instead.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#224] Dashboard: restore view state using query parameters (#160)
commitResults.messageBody:
The summary dashboard plays an important role in highlighting and
filtering the report data to provide the most relevant view for the
users.

Permalinks was a feature implemented in the previous dashboard that
enables the users to quickly save the state of the dashboard to quickly
return to it when needed.

While useful, this feature was not core to the usage of the dashboard,
hence left out during the feature for feature reimplementation during
the dashboard structural changes.

Lets implement this permalink feature in the main vue module. New
fields will be emitted from their individual modules into the global
object.

The summary module will read the information from the global object
then load the filtered view accordingly.

Implementing it in the main modules also provides us the option of
opening up other modules for the permalink features if needed in the
future.

commitResults.messageTitle: Dashboard: fix incompatibility with Microsoft Edge (#252)
commitResults.messageBody:
Microsoft Edges does not support the full set of features available in
the ES6 specification, amongst which, includes the object spread
operator. [1]

Let's remove the usage of the object spread operator so allow the
dashboard to be run from edge browser.

[1] Discussion on Edge's support for object spread operator
https://github.com/Polymer/tools/issues/173

commitResults.messageTitle: [#209] Dashboard: hide overflow elements (#251)
commitResults.messageBody:
"label" tag seems to be greater than the height allocated to it by the
render engine. This results in the "scrollbar" arrows popping up to
show the users the "full content".

This can be distracting for users when they are trying to navigate the
site. Let's remove this scrollbar arrows by applying the "overflow-y:
hidden" CSS setting to the filter labels.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#254] Fix dashboard unable to load authorship.json file (#253)
commitResults.messageBody:
When trying to open up the right side tab panel to load the authorship
information, the file not found error pops up, and the panel stays
blank.

Turns out, the error was introduced when we were trying to package all
the information into a single object when passing it into the module.
To fix this, let's update the way the directory whereby the file is
being loaded.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#189] Dashboard: fix ramps z-index value (#255)
commitResults.messageBody:
Ramps representing very huge commits will be rendered as a very
humongous triangle. This display blocks up the commits in the earlier
periods, hence causing them to be unclickable.

To fix this, let's render the ramps such that the earlier ramps will
have a larger z-index value to place it on top of the more recent
ramps. This ensures that users will be able to interact with all the
ramps.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#263] Add timezone to ramp's github redirect link (#266)
commitResults.messageBody:
Occasionally, clicking a ramp will show no commits found for the
specified user. This is because our git log command uses a constant
timezone (Singapore UTC+8) and this mis-align with the GitHub time
system.

Let's fix this by adding the timezone to the github redirect link as
well.

commitResults.messageTitle: Dashboard: enable search to use multiple keywords (#256)
commitResults.messageBody:
Current search function filter the authors/repositories using exact
sentence match. 

However, it may be more useful for users to be able to search using
multiple keywords.

Let's modify the search filter to pick out the results based on params
separated by spaces using or search technique.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#264] Code view: add total number of lines contributed for each file (#282)
commitResults.messageBody:
Code panel could use more useful information such as number of lines
contributed for each file. This would give the reviewer a rough idea
how many lines the author has contributed to each component.

Let's add the line of code information into the display.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#270] Dashboard: remove unused tabs bar in the code view (#285)
commitResults.messageBody:
Code view only has a single page, which makes the addition of tabs bar
serves no purpose at this stage

Let's remove it since its not in used.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#259] Dashboard: add an indicator to code view (#287)
commitResults.messageBody:
New users may not know all the functionalities that are available to
them, hence hidden functionalities such as code view may go unnoticed.

To enhance our user friendliness, let's add a tool-tip and icon to the
ramp chart title so that the code view feature stands out more
intuitively.

commitResults.messageTitle: Dashboard: add indication to empty state in code view #291
commitResults.messageBody:
Code view lacks a empty state. This creates a confusion as there is no
visualization change between the loading and loaded stage for empty
data.

Let's add a message to indicate the loading has completed in the event
where there is nothing to show.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#258] Dashboard: optimize settings bar to fit various screen sizes (#286)
commitResults.messageBody:
Settings bar does not degrade gracefully for smaller screen sizes.

This make the ui looks disorganized and messy.

Let's readjust the font size, grouping and margin to make the settings
bar looks neater.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#267] Reduce memory cache in code view (#290)
commitResults.messageBody:
Code view caches the past loaded repository's authorship data to avoid
repetitive loading which increases the response time.

However, this can cause the memory usage to keep increasing as
more and more repository's authorship data gets stored as cache.

As users are unlikely to revisit repositories that were loaded long
ago, let's preserve only the most recent 2 repository's authorship data
as cache.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#289] Code view: tweak code packing algorithm (#292)
commitResults.messageBody:
Untouched code segments that are smaller than minimum lines are
displayed together with the touched code. This distorts the truth as
these code do not belong to the author and may lead to unnecessary
disputes.

Let's encapsulate untouched code in the expand box only if >5 lines but
still differentiate them using color irregardless.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#304] Fix TypeError: "commits[0] is undefined" (#303)
commitResults.messageBody:
For authors with absolutely no commit history,  v_summary runs into
trouble trying to determine the date range of the commits.

Let's do a check before calculating the date range of the commits.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#321] Dashboard: add landing page link in footer (#326)
commitResults.messageBody:
Dashboard footer displays only the generated timestamp.

This does not credit RepoSense in anyway, also user may not know how to
use the dashboard.

Let's include a link to direct user to RepoSense landing page.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#336] Dashboard crashes when modify date to be out of range (#339)
commitResults.messageBody:
When we try to modify the date of the Since or Until filter in the
dashboard, if the date specified is out of range, like setting year
2020 for until date, or any year for the since date (since typing the
1st number will set it to be that year 1st), the dashboard will hang,
and 66crash.

Let's fix this by adding a validation check, to ensure that the
filter dates are within the analysis date range.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#358] Report#datepicker: default value not filled on initial load (#359)
commitResults.messageBody:
The date picker does not display the date range of summary view on
load.

Let's obtain the date picker value from the hash param if provided,
otherwise, set it to be the minimum and maximum dates of the generated
report by default.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#409] Fix Gradle task npmRunSpuild not working as intended (#410)
commitResults.messageBody:
The recent update on the spuild library has caused the gradle task,
npmRunSpuild, to deviate from our expected functionality and no longer
builds our frontend files as before.

Let's fix this by removing the caret sign in the package.json to retain
the last working version of spuild we used for the rendering of the
dashboard.

commitResults.messageTitle: DeveloperGuide: update documentation for frontend (#242)
commitResults.messageBody:
The new dashboard doesn't come with the updated development
documentation. And this can prove troublesome for new developers as
they will have to spend a lot of time in the current codebase to make
sense of how the dashboard is structured.

Let's include a short writeup of the dashboard framework to help
explain how the data is being rendered more clearly.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#373] Fix typing lag in the report search bar (#495)
commitResults.messageBody:
Typing in the report search bar seems to be a bit laggy on the
dashboard-demo. Investigation reveals that lag is caused by the vue
object trying to rewrite the `v_model` on every keystroke.

Let's update and trigger the search only when the typing is complete,
ie we will be updating the summary view as triggered by the `onchange`
event of the search filter `input`.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#502] Enable ESLint JavaScript linter on travis (#514)
commitResults.messageBody:
ESLint was implemented, however it doesn't seems to be enforcing
style check on any of the CI platforms. 

This is due to the glob that was passed into eslint was incorrect which
causes it to skip the js files.

Let's modify the glob string to enable the javascript linter, and also
fixed the violations that were found.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#468] Add per-commit granularity to the report (#500)
commitResults.messageBody:
The dashboard only allows summary view for daily and weekly
granularities.

While the daily and weekly intervals give the reviewer the rough
impression of the authors' workload, it does not provide any insights
on the authors' commit frequency, commit organization and merged
changes. These information are important in helping users to further
understand the authors' workflow and contribution.

Let's implement summary view for per commit granularity. To do so,
let's update `commits.json` report to store the list of each
CommitResult inside the daily interval contribution data, and update
the frontend implement the per commit granularity using this data.

As the weekly interval view is now generated on the frontend based
on the daily view by #129, there is no longer a need to store the
weekly interval contribution data in commits.json.

Let's also remove the weekly interval contribution data in
`commits.json` report to reduce the size of the json files.

commitResults.messageTitle: Refactor window.location.hash update methods (#558)
commitResults.messageBody:
`window.location.hash` is used and updated in multiple places.
This results in duplication of code for writing to and using of
hash parameters.

Let's refactor the way we update the location hash by creating
functions for accessing and using hashes: `addHash`, `removeHash`,
`encodeHash` and `decodeHash`.

All these functions will be implemented with `window.hashParams` as the
main way of access and writing to `location.hash`.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#585] Fix linearly unsynchronous ramp charts (#591)
commitResults.messageBody:
Checks are performed on the dates prior to every update of the ramp
chart's filter.

However, the checks only accounts for cases where the dates are valid,
checking that they are within the given range. When an invalid date
such as "2019-02-31" is given, the checks are bypassed, causing
ramp charts of different repositories to have different end dates and
linearly unsynchronous.

Let's add an additional check to ensure that valid dates were
given before we update the filter fields.

commitResults.messageTitle: Refactor toolbar into v-authorship tab (#566)
commitResults.messageBody:
The toolbar for the "expand/collapse all" text is outside of the
v-authorship tab.

This shouldn't be the case as it makes it difficult to extend and
include other kinds of tabs.

Let's shift the toolbar into the v-authorship tab, and make some
corresponding changes to how the toggle state is changed.

This will keep the toolbar within the authorship tab, which makes sense
as the button is only relevant for the authorship tab. In light that we
are going to have other kinds of tabs to extend the use of the side tab
in the future.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#603] GitLog: replace author date with commit date (#641)
commitResults.messageBody:
The ramps in report are placed according to the authored date to
visualize the actual timeline when the authors make their
contribution.

However, GitHub repos use commit date in their timeline. This leads to
discrepancy when performing comparison with the GitHub platform.
Furthermore, this is also the factor causing the url on the ramps
directing users to incorrect dated commit list web page.

To make our product coherent to GitHub users, let's change to use
commit dates for our ramp chart.

commitResults.messageTitle: Report: Add zoom in feature for ramp charts (#573)
commitResults.messageBody:
The commit granularity setting for the ramp chart slice produces a ramp 
chart that may be too dense to reveal any substantial information. 

Let's add a side panel that provides a zoomed-in view of the ramp 
chart, selected based on a specified time frame.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#667] Report: fix search bar not displaying value provided by url parameter (#676)
commitResults.messageBody:
Search bar component is not displaying the value that is provided 
by the URL parameter.

This confuses users into thinking that only the listed authors and 
repos are all that's captured by the system, when there are others 
which are filtered out.

Let's fix this bug by adding a two-way binding that binds the search 
field and the corresponding JavaScript filterSearch variable.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#695] Report: allow reset of date controls (#700)
commitResults.messageBody:
Pressing the "X" button in the date field only clears the 
date, with no useful functionality.

Users who wish to go back to the default dates will 
need to manually pick the dates from the date picker,
which can be troublesome.

Let's reset the "since date" and "until date" to the earliest and 
latest date respectively, should the user clear the date in the 
respective boxes.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#506] Report: add checks to ensure that .zip file is uploaded (#693)
commitResults.messageBody:
Uploaded files are not checked if the file type is of .zip file.

No alerts will be shown to the user and nothing will happen if they 
were to upload non .zip files to the web page.

Let's check if the uploaded file is .zip file, and show an alert to 
the user if the user uploaded a non .zip file to the web page.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#681,#756] UG: update in accordance to change in Toolbar (#696)
commitResults.messageBody:
The recent changes in the toolbar component of the report view are not 
reflected in the user guide, especially the `group by` function.

When users want to seek the explanation for the `group by`
functionality, they may not understand as the relevant sections in user
guide are outdated.

Let's update the user guide to reflect the changes made to the Toolbar.
Let's also take this chance to rephrase certain descriptions that are
outdated or misleading.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#721] Report: remove usage of spread operator (#766)
commitResults.messageBody:
Microsoft Edge browser does not support spread operator in JavaScript 
ES6.

Users using Microsoft Edge will not be able to load the report.

Let's remove the usage of spread operator so as to allow the report
to be run from Microsoft Edge browser.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#711] Analysis: ignore binary files (#728)
commitResults.messageBody:
Binary files are included in the commits analysis and are shown in the
report view as interpreted plain text.

The produced results are gibberish; junks that do not make sense and
not useful to the readers.

Let's exclude binary files from the analysis.

The method implemented to determine whether a file is binary or not is 
by utilizing "git diff" functionality return a list of committed files 
with the number of lines added and deleted. A file is deemed to be 
binary when the number of lines added and deleted are both "-".

commitResults.messageTitle: [#683,#688] Limit range of commits to one month if "since date" is not specified (#690)
commitResults.messageBody:
"since date", when not specified, defaults to the date of the first
commit. 

Analyzing repos with large number of commits can take up a
long time, which may leave a bad impression for first time users.

Let's,
* limit the range of commits to be captured to one month, if
"since date" is not specified.
* allow `--since *` as a shorthand to specify the date of the first
commit without knowing the actual date.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#781] Fix broken program when reserved character is used without escaping (#782)
commitResults.messageBody:
Following #690, asterisk is used in since date argument as a shorthand
to the date of the first commit.

As asterisk is also a reserved character in shell, using it without
escaping cause the program to be unusable.

Let's change the shorthand to d1 so it can be used directly without the
need to escape.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#567] Report#Zip: remove unrelated files and folders (#656)
commitResults.messageBody:
Zipped files currently contain irrelevant files and/or folders. 

Some users may dump other irrelevant files/folders into 
the same directory as the directory for the repos to be 
cloned into. This results in irrelevant files and folders being 
included in the zip file, which is not intended to be.

Let's zip only the relevant repo folders and the 
corresponding .JSON files into the zip file. 

This method utilizes the existing class `RepoConfiguration` , to
get the list of repos report to be zipped.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#738] CsvParser: fix incorrect splitting of literals commas (#739)
commitResults.messageBody:
We parse CSV by using comma as a delimiter.

When commas are used in a column as value, by enclosing double quotes,
they are mistakenly treated as a delimiter. This results in incorrect
parsing of values.

Let's use third-party CSV parser library, Apache Commons CSV to
handle the intricacies of CSV parsing in a correct and clean
manner.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#531,#707] Analysis: use all formats by default (#708)
commitResults.messageBody:
By default, a set of common programming file formats is used for
analysis. To override the default set, one would need the knowledge of
the file formats used in their repository.

Let's,
* simplify this process by using all file formats present in the
repository by default.
* fix the wrong detection of full directory path instead of filename for
files without file extensions.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#671, #750] CommitInfo: capture commits' message body (#751)
commitResults.messageBody:
In the zoom tab, only the commit titles were listed.

The commit message title alone may be too abstract for users to 
understand the rationale of large implementations.

Let's capture the commit message body as well and store it in
commits report.

This is a backend implementation of capturing message body to aid 
in the implementation of displaying commit message body in the 
zoom tab.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#305] Make -config an optional parameter (#318)
commitResults.messageBody:
-config is a mandatory param that has to be entered, to perform an
analysis using config files. In some scenarios, users may chose to 
target their current working directory as the config files folder. 

As programs have knowledge of its current working directory, it can be
redundant for users to specify this information to the program. 

To improve the user-friendliness, let's change -config to become an
optional parameter by setting the default config files directory to cwd.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#345] Allow nonexistent folder in -output param (#348)
commitResults.messageBody:
If the output path specified by the user does not exist, the program
exits with a 'folder not found' error message.

Let's automatically create the output folder for such cases
as it is more convenient to the user and is the norm in most software.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#323] Make branch an optional field (#332)
commitResults.messageBody:
By default when git clones a repository, it will be at the base
(GitHub) or working (local) branch.

Checking out to master is a redundant step that doesn't guarantee that
we will be analyzing the base/working branch.

Let's configure RepoSense to treat the current working branch as the
base for analysis.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#456] ChartView: show breakdown of file formats in Contribution Bar (#487)
commitResults.messageBody:
Contribution Bar is a single red bar which represents total
contribution of the author, without any additional information.

Providing a breakdown by file format in the Contribution Bar allows
users to view the file format used in a repository, and compare
contributions by file formats with a quick glance at the Chart Panel,
without having to open the Code Panel.

Let's reflect the breakdown of file formats in Contribution Bar.

The user can hover over a specific section of the Contribution Bar
to see information about the file formats, total lines contributed
and analysis period in the tooltip.

The user can refer to the legend below a repo name in the chart view
to determine which color represents which file formats.

If the user has specified file formats, the Contribution Bar and legend
reflects only those file formats, in order specified by user.
Otherwise, the file formats are sorted alphabetically.

Since this file format information is being processed in the front-end
in code view (v_authorship), let's move the processing of file format
information to the backend in order to be able to use the pre-processed
file format information for both chart view (v_summary) and code view
(v_authorship). Let's also refactor the file format processing in
code-view (v_authorship) to match the changes being made.

commitResults.messageTitle: Gradle: replace build with shadowJar plugin (#68)
commitResults.messageBody:
Gradle build compiles our source files and libraries used in the
program into separate jar files, and delivers the entire package as
a zip file.

It is rather inconvenient as user would have to extract from the zip
file to use it and also have more unnecessary files to deal with.
Additionally, if we package only our own class files into the JAR
file, it will not work properly unless the user has all the other 
JAR files (i.e. third party libraries) our classes depend on.

Let's replace the gradle build with shadowJar plugin to package all
dependencies into a single JAR file which enhance usability and
portability.

Let's replace the gradle build with shadowJar plugin to package all
dependencies into a single JAR file which enhance usability and
portability.

commitResults.messageTitle: Fix datetime inconsistency (#125)

Several date time inconsistency exists in the project.
1. Instead of designated constants, raw values are being used in month
   field of Calender setter.

   execution.

This leads to disagreeing outputs when running the program at
different timing or on different machine.

Let's fix the date time inconsistency by
1. using the designated constants,
2. and fixed formatted values.

There are 2 main templates loaded separately to process the information
from the generated report. This requires the same template files to be
regenerated multiple times, which greatly increases the size of the
generated report unnecessarily. Ideally, it should only contains the
data for the report.

better utilize the framework to restructure the dashboard into a single
page application which loads content from the report dynamically.

[#277] Make authors configuration completely optional (#294)
commitResults.messageBody:
Author's information is compulsory in configuration; RepoSense requires
the user to configure an author-config.csv or have the repository owner
put up their own configuration.

This, however, creates a hurdle for the new users to overcome as they
would need to build up the configuration before trying out our tool.

Let's improve the first impression of our tool by making authors
configuration completely optional. All the authors found in history
will be added to the analysis in the event that no author configuration
was found for the repository.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#311] code view: differentiate untouched code more (#314)
commitResults.messageBody:
Untouched code uses the same background and font color as written
code.

This allows the possibility of it being passed off as written code
(i.e., give the viewer an impression that the author changed more code
than she actually did) because the only way to differentiate the two
types of code is the color of the line in the gutter.

Let's differentiate the two code types more by adding a light green 
background to written code.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#325] Replace the usage of findstr and grep (#324)
commitResults.messageBody:
We use terminal functions, findstr and grep, to filter the results of
command execution.

This requires us to append os dependent command and also subject to the
limitation of these libraries.

For example, findstr does not support proper regex and has no limiting
quantifier support. This can exposes us to problems when searching for 
patterns that cannot be resolved with the regex of findstr.

Let's replace the use of this 2 functions with our own regex-based text
filtration method, StringsUtil#filterText.

quantifier support. This can exposes us to problems when searching for 
patterns that cannot be resolved with the regex of findstr.

Let's replace the use of this 2 functions with our own regex-based text
filtration method, StringsUtil#filterText.

Length of the contribution bars varies, dependent on the set of
displayed authors.

This should not be the case. The scale used for the bar should be fixed
for a given period irrespective of which authors are displayed. Search
filters should simply filter out certain authors without changing
anything else.

calculation instead of filtered.

only perform this calculation once and store the value in a global
constant.

commitResults.messageTitle: Fix error occurred from file change due to permission bits modification (#356)
commitResults.messageBody:
We use git diff to extract file infos. In particular rare cases, our
code fails to extracting relevant file infos for certain commits, due
to special extended header lines `old mode 100644` 
`new mode 100755` returned by the git diff, it throws an
AssertionError halfway during the analysis.

This is due to git, besides the file content and changes, it also
tracks the executable bit of the files' permission. As our program did
not foresee this scenario, it crashes upon the occurrence.

Let's fix this by inserting additional guard clause for this scenario
in our FileInfoExtractor.

commitResults.messageTitle: Fix error occurred from file change due to permission bits modification (#356)
commitResults.messageBody:
We use git diff to extract file infos. In particular rare cases, our
code fails to extracting relevant file infos for certain commits, due
to special extended header lines `old mode 100644` 
`new mode 100755` returned by the git diff, it throws an
AssertionError halfway during the analysis.

This is due to git, besides the file content and changes, it also
tracks the executable bit of the files' permission. As our program did
not foresee this scenario, it crashes upon the occurrence.

Let's fix this by inserting additional guard clause for this scenario
in our FileInfoExtractor.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#363] Make the commits info analysis case insensitive (#364)
commitResults.messageBody:
CommitInfoExtractor uses git log to extract users' commits info.
However, by default, the author matching pattern used in git log is
case sensitive.

This can cause the CommitInfoAnalyzer to miss out some or all their
commits in the analysis. As a result, some authors do not have any
ramps shown in their ramp chart, even though their code view shows line
contributions.

To resolve this problem, let's set the git log regex patterns to be
case insensitive.

To resolve this problem, let's set the git log regex patterns to be
case insensitive.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#395] Fix unhandled IllegalArgumentException in RepoConfiguration#update (#397)
commitResults.messageBody:
Standalone config goes through validation check before being utilized
for analysis. In the event where standalone configs contain invalid
value(s), RepoSense will indicate it by throwing an
IllegalArgumentException.

However, in #395, a standalone config with invalid `ignoreCommitList`
was found in one of the repositories which has caused an intermediate
crash during the analysis. This is due to the IllegalArgumentException
not being properly handled.

Let's handle the IllegalArgumentException by ignoring the standalone
config, also, ensure that none of the fields prior to validation.

Standalone config goes through validation check before being utilized
for analysis. In the event where standalone configs contain invalid
value(s), RepoSense will indicate it by throwing an
IllegalArgumentException.

However, in #395, a standalone config with invalid `ignoreCommitList`
was found in one of the repositories which has caused an intermediate
crash during the analysis. This is due to the IllegalArgumentException
not being properly handled.

Let's handle the IllegalArgumentException by ignoring the standalone
config, also, ensure that none of the fields prior to validation.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#391, #398, #399] Hotfix for outburst of RuntimeException (#400)
commitResults.messageBody:
Due to the nature of our application, and the lack of simpler
alternatives, our application heavily relies on the external command
line utility, `git`. To make use of the tool, we employed a
CommandRunner class which starts a separate process to execute various
operations.

This, however, encourages the outbreak of RuntimeException as numerous
factors can cause `git` to return a non-zero status code and
CommandRunner allows these exceptions to go unchecked.

To prevent RuntimeException from interrupting the analysis of multiple
repos, let's skip the repo under analysis whenever a RunTimeException
occurs.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#310] Apply SRP to various git commands (#408)
commitResults.messageBody:
All the git commands are embedded in the CommandRunner class.

This violates the Single Responsibility Principle as CommandRunner
should only be responsible for the execution, and not the type of
commands.

As a step towards deprecating the use of CommandRunner, let's export
the commands to respective classes and remove the direct dependency on
CommandRunner.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#471] Fix broken link on ramps (#472)

the url links are undefined.

This is due the change in #425 where we encapsulate the names in
another layer of abstraction.

Let's fix the property accessors in v_summary.js to restore the broken
hyperlink.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#375] Config: add new parameter - author's email (#493)
commitResults.messageBody:
When merging a pull request on the GitHub platform, GitHub uses the
author's profile name as the Author Name in the merge commit. Unlike
RepoSense which uses Author Name(s) in tracking the authors'
contribution, GitHub uses emails to track the authors' activity. 

This can however pose a problem to our users. When the authors change
their profile name, they will need to update their list of aliases in
the config files correspondingly in order to maintain the trackability
of RepoSense which can be a hassle to our users.

To provide better experience to our users, let's add the email field to
our csv and json configuration files.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#399] Fix RuntimeException due to ambiguous argument in git rev-list (#505)
commitResults.messageBody:
When a file with the same name as the analyzing branch exist in the
repo, an uncaught RuntimeException will occur due to ambiguous argument
in git rev-list causing RepoSense to crash.

Let's add the `--` revision-path separator in `git rev-list` command to
distinguish the branch name from the ambiguous argument.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#587] Fix unoriented output messages (#593)
commitResults.messageBody:
Some of the messages used in RepoSense are structurally unoriented.

This include the missing transition message where --config flag is
unused, using default path for analysis and the double printing of
the help message, and the confusing arrangement of usage parameters as
shown in #587.

Let's fix these scenarios to improve the quality of our output messages.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#622] CsvParser#parse: fix error handling of `processLine` (#623)
commitResults.messageBody:
When processing a line that is illegal or erroneous, `processLine` will
throw an exception to the caller, `parse`, and the process gets
terminated.

This result in the rise of an issue in
nus-cs3281/2019-dashboard@ef0791f where a misconfigured line in
author-config.csv causes the subsequent lines of authors not being
parsed and added to the analysis.

As the lines in our csv config are meant to be separate entities, let's
ignore any misconfigurations and move on to parsing the subsequent
lines.

commitResults.messageTitle: [#199] Clean docs of confusing dates (#415)
commitResults.messageBody:
The sample dates given in the User Guide and Developer Guide use a day
that is lower than 12.

This makes the day fits the month criteria which can cause confusion to
readers and mixing up the correct date format. This has unnecessary
increase the perplexity of our documentation and needs to be
changed.

Let's change the "dd" part of the dates in the examples to be above 12
so that there will be no bafflement between the day and month fields.
